cwe.description: The product uses a cookie to store sensitive information, but the cookie is not marked with the HttpOnly flag.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>If the HttpOnly flag is not set, then sensitive information stored in the cookie may be exposed to unintended parties.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>If the cookie in question is an authentication cookie, then not setting the HttpOnly flag may allow an adversary to steal authentication data (e.g., a session ID) and assume the identity of the user.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product uses a cookie to store sensitive information, but the cookie is not marked with the HttpOnly flag.
cwe.name: Sensitive Cookie Without 'HttpOnly' Flag
cwe.extended_summary: The HttpOnly flag directs compatible browsers to prevent client-side script from accessing cookies. Including the HttpOnly flag in the Set-Cookie HTTP response header helps mitigate the risk associated with Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) where an attacker's script code might attempt to read the contents of a cookie and exfiltrate information obtained. When set, browsers that support the flag will not reveal the contents of the cookie to a third party via client-side script executed via XSS.

cwe.description: The product displays information or identifiers to a user, but the display mechanism does not make it easy for the user to distinguish between visually similar or identical glyphs (homoglyphs), which may cause the user to misinterpret a glyph and perform an unintended, insecure action.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Other</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>An attacker may ultimately redirect a user to a malicious website, by deceiving the user into believing the URL they are accessing is a trusted domain. However, the attack can also be used to forge log entries by using homoglyphs in usernames. Homoglyph manipulations are often the first step towards executing advanced attacks such as stealing a user's credentials, Cross-Site Scripting (XSS), or log forgery. If an attacker redirects a user to a malicious site, the attacker can mimic a trusted domain to steal account credentials and perform actions on behalf of the user, without the user's knowledge. Similarly, an attacker could create a username for a website that contains homoglyph characters, making it difficult for an admin to review logs and determine which users performed which actions.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product displays information or identifiers to a user, but the display mechanism does not make it easy for the user to distinguish between visually similar or identical glyphs (homoglyphs), which may cause the user to misinterpret a glyph and perform an unintended, insecure action.
cwe.name: Insufficient Visual Distinction of Homoglyphs Presented to User
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <html:p>Some glyphs, pictures, or icons can be semantically distinct to a program, while appearing very similar or identical to a human user. These are referred to as homoglyphs. For example, the lowercase "l" (ell) and uppercase "I" (eye) have different character codes, but these characters can be displayed in exactly the same way to a user, depending on the font. This can also occur between different character sets. For example, the Latin capital letter "A" and the Greek capital letter "Α" (Alpha) are treated as distinct by programs, but may be displayed in exactly the same way to a user. Accent marks may also cause letters to appear very similar, such as the Latin capital letter grave mark "À" and its equivalent "Á" with the acute accent.</html:p>
            <html:p>Adversaries can exploit this visual similarity for attacks such as phishing, e.g. by providing a link to an attacker-controlled hostname that looks like a hostname that the victim trusts. In a different use of homoglyphs, an adversary may create a back door username that is visually similar to the username of a regular user, which then makes it more difficult for a system administrator to detect the malicious username while reviewing logs.</html:p>
         </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: The product uses multiple validation forms with the same name, which might cause the Struts Validator to validate a form that the programmer does not expect.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Unexpected State</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product uses multiple validation forms with the same name, which might cause the Struts Validator to validate a form that the programmer does not expect.
cwe.name: Struts: Duplicate Validation Forms
cwe.extended_summary: If two validation forms have the same name, the Struts Validator arbitrarily chooses one of the forms to use for input validation and discards the other. This decision might not correspond to the programmer's expectations, possibly leading to resultant weaknesses. Moreover, it indicates that the validation logic is not up-to-date, and can indicate that other, more subtle validation errors are present.

cwe.description: The web application does not restrict or incorrectly restricts frame objects or UI layers that belong to another application or domain, which can lead to user confusion about which interface the user is interacting with.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Bypass Protection Mechanism</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>An attacker can trick a user into performing actions that are masked and hidden from the user's view. The impact varies widely, depending on the functionality of the underlying application. For example, in a social media application, clickjacking could be used to trik the user into changing privacy settings.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The web application does not restrict or incorrectly restricts frame objects or UI layers that belong to another application or domain, which can lead to user confusion about which interface the user is interacting with.
cwe.name: Improper Restriction of Rendered UI Layers or Frames
cwe.extended_summary: A web application is expected to place restrictions on whether it is allowed to be rendered within frames, iframes, objects, embed or applet elements. Without the restrictions, users can be tricked into interacting with the application when they were not intending to.

cwe.description: The web application produces links to untrusted external sites outside of its sphere of control, but it does not properly prevent the external site from modifying  security-critical properties of the window.opener object, such as the location property.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Alter Execution Logic</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>The user may be redirected to an untrusted page that contains undesired content or malicious script code.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The web application produces links to untrusted external sites outside of its sphere of control, but it does not properly prevent the external site from modifying  security-critical properties of the window.opener object, such as the location property.
cwe.name: Use of Web Link to Untrusted Target with window.opener Access
cwe.extended_summary: When a user clicks a link to an external site ("target"), the target="_blank" attribute causes the target site's contents to be opened in a new window or tab, which runs in the same process as the original page. The window.opener object records information about the original page that offered the link.  If an attacker can run script on the target page, then they could read or modify certain properties of the window.opener object, including the location property - even if the original and target site are not the same origin.  An attacker can modify the location property to automatically redirect the user to a malicious site, e.g. as part of a phishing attack. Since this redirect happens in the original window/tab - which is not necessarily visible, since the browser is focusing the display on the new target page - the user might not notice any suspicious redirection.

cwe.description: The product performs a comparison between entities that must consider multiple factors or characteristics of each entity, but the comparison does not include one or more of these factors.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Alter Execution Logic</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Bypass Protection Mechanism</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product performs a comparison between entities that must consider multiple factors or characteristics of each entity, but the comparison does not include one or more of these factors.
cwe.name: Incomplete Comparison with Missing Factors
cwe.extended_summary: An incomplete comparison can lead to resultant weaknesses, e.g., by operating on the wrong object or making a security decision without considering a required factor.

cwe.description: The product performs a comparison between two entities, but the entities are of different, incompatible types that cannot be guaranteed to provide correct results when they are directly compared.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Varies by Context</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product performs a comparison between two entities, but the entities are of different, incompatible types that cannot be guaranteed to provide correct results when they are directly compared.
cwe.name: Comparison of Incompatible Types
cwe.extended_summary: In languages that are strictly typed but support casting/conversion, such as C or C++, the programmer might assume that casting one entity to the same type as another entity will ensure that the comparison will be performed correctly, but this cannot be guaranteed.  In languages that are not strictly typed, such as PHP or JavaScript, there may be implicit casting/conversion to a type that the programmer is unaware of, causing unexpected results; for example, the string "123" might be converted to a number type.  See examples.

cwe.description: The code performs a comparison between two entities, but the comparison examines the wrong factors or characteristics of the entities, which can lead to incorrect results and resultant weaknesses.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Varies by Context</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The code performs a comparison between two entities, but the comparison examines the wrong factors or characteristics of the entities, which can lead to incorrect results and resultant weaknesses.
cwe.name: Comparison Using Wrong Factors
cwe.extended_summary: This can lead to incorrect results and resultant weaknesses.  For example, the code might inadvertently compare references to objects, instead of the relevant contents of those objects, causing two "equal" objects to be considered unequal.

cwe.description: The product has a validator form that either does not define a validate() method, or defines a validate() method but does not call super.validate().
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Other</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>Disabling the validation framework for a form exposes the product to numerous types of attacks. Unchecked input is the root cause of vulnerabilities like cross-site scripting, process control, and SQL injection.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Other</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>Although J2EE applications are not generally susceptible to memory corruption attacks, if a J2EE application interfaces with native code that does not perform array bounds checking, an attacker may be able to use an input validation mistake in the J2EE application to launch a buffer overflow attack.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product has a validator form that either does not define a validate() method, or defines a validate() method but does not call super.validate().
cwe.name: Struts: Incomplete validate() Method Definition
cwe.extended_summary: If the code does not call super.validate(), the Validation Framework cannot check the contents of the form against a validation form. In other words, the validation framework will be disabled for the given form.

cwe.description: The developer builds a security-critical protection mechanism into the software, but the processor optimizes the execution of the program such that the mechanism is removed or modified.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Bypass Protection Mechanism</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Likelihood>High</ns0:Likelihood>
               <ns0:Note>A successful exploitation of this weakness will change the order of an application's execution and will likely be used to bypass specific protection mechanisms. This bypass can be exploited further to potentially read data that should otherwise be unaccessible.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The developer builds a security-critical protection mechanism into the software, but the processor optimizes the execution of the program such that the mechanism is removed or modified.
cwe.name: Processor Optimization Removal or Modification of Security-critical Code

cwe.description: The product uses a mechanism that automatically optimizes code, e.g. to improve a characteristic such as performance, but the optimizations can have an unintended side effect that might violate an intended security assumption.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Alter Execution Logic</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>The optimizations alter the order of execution resulting in side effects that were not intended by the original developer.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product uses a mechanism that automatically optimizes code, e.g. to improve a characteristic such as performance, but the optimizations can have an unintended side effect that might violate an intended security assumption.
cwe.name: Insecure Automated Optimizations

cwe.description: The product uses an automated mechanism such as machine learning to recognize complex data inputs (e.g. image or audio) as a particular concept or category, but it does not properly detect or handle inputs that have been modified or constructed in a way that causes the mechanism to detect a different, incorrect concept.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Bypass Protection Mechanism</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>When the automated recognition is used in a protection mechanism, an attacker may be able to craft inputs that are misinterpreted in a way that grants excess privileges.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product uses an automated mechanism such as machine learning to recognize complex data inputs (e.g. image or audio) as a particular concept or category, but it does not properly detect or handle inputs that have been modified or constructed in a way that causes the mechanism to detect a different, incorrect concept.
cwe.name: Automated Recognition Mechanism with Inadequate Detection or Handling of Adversarial Input Perturbations
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <html:p>When techniques such as machine learning are used to automatically classify input streams, and those classifications are used for security-critical decisions, then any mistake in classification can introduce a vulnerability that allows attackers to cause the product to make the wrong security decision.  If the automated mechanism is not developed or "trained" with enough input data, then attackers may be able to craft malicious input that intentionally triggers the incorrect classification.</html:p>
            <html:p>Targeted technologies include, but are not necessarily limited to:</html:p>
            <html:ul>
               <html:li>automated speech recognition</html:li>
               <html:li>automated image recognition</html:li>
            </html:ul>
            <html:p>For example, an attacker might modify road signs or road surface markings to trick autonomous vehicles into misreading the sign/marking and performing a dangerous action.</html:p>
         </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: If a form bean does not extend an ActionForm subclass of the Validator framework, it can expose the application to other weaknesses related to insufficient input validation.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Other</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>Bypassing the validation framework for a form exposes the application to numerous types of attacks. Unchecked input is an important component of vulnerabilities like cross-site scripting, process control, and SQL injection.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Other</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>Although J2EE applications are not generally susceptible to memory corruption attacks, if a J2EE application interfaces with native code that does not perform array bounds checking, an attacker may be able to use an input validation mistake in the J2EE application to launch a buffer overflow attack.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: If a form bean does not extend an ActionForm subclass of the Validator framework, it can expose the application to other weaknesses related to insufficient input validation.
cwe.name: Struts: Form Bean Does Not Extend Validation Class

cwe.description:
The product has multiple functions, methods, procedures, macros, etc. that
					contain the same code.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Reduce Maintainability</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary:
The product has multiple functions, methods, procedures, macros, etc. that
					contain the same code.
cwe.name: Use of Redundant Code
cwe.extended_summary: b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7"><html:p>This issue makes it more difficult to maintain the product, which indirectly affects security by making it more difficult or time-consuming to find and/or fix vulnerabilities.  For example, if there are two copies of the same code, the programmer might fix a weakness in one copy while forgetting to fix the same weakness in another copy.</html:p></ns0:Extended_Description>\n         '

cwe.description:
The code contains a member element that is declared as static (but not final), in which
					its parent class element 
					is not a singleton class - that is, a class element that can be used only once in
					the 'to' association of a Create action.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Reduce Performance</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary:
The code contains a member element that is declared as static (but not final), in which
					its parent class element 
					is not a singleton class - that is, a class element that can be used only once in
					the 'to' association of a Create action.
cwe.name: Static Member Data Element outside of a Singleton Class Element
cwe.extended_summary: b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7"><html:p>This issue can make the product perform more slowly.  If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker, then this performance problem might introduce a vulnerability.</html:p></ns0:Extended_Description>\n         '

cwe.description:
The product uses a data element that has an excessively large
					number of sub-elements with non-primitive data types such as structures or aggregated objects.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Reduce Performance</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary:
The product uses a data element that has an excessively large
					number of sub-elements with non-primitive data types such as structures or aggregated objects.
cwe.name: Data Element Aggregating an Excessively Large Number of Non-Primitive Elements
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7"><html:p>This issue can make the product perform more slowly.  If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker, then this performance problem might introduce a vulnerability.</html:p>
		 <html:p>While the interpretation of "excessively large" may vary for each product or developer, CISQ recommends a default of 5 sub-elements.</html:p>
		 </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description:
The product's architecture contains too many - or too few -
					horizontal layers.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Reduce Maintainability</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary:
The product's architecture contains too many - or too few -
					horizontal layers.
cwe.name: Architecture with Number of Horizontal Layers Outside of Expected Range
cwe.extended_summary: b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7"><html:p>This issue makes it more difficult to maintain the product, which indirectly affects security by making it more difficult or time-consuming to find and/or fix vulnerabilities.  It also might make it easier to introduce vulnerabilities.</html:p>\n\t\t <html:p>While the interpretation of "expected range" may vary for each product or developer, CISQ recommends a default minimum of 4 layers and maximum of 8 layers.</html:p></ns0:Extended_Description>\n         '

cwe.description: A parent class has a virtual destructor method, but the parent has a child class that does not have a virtual destructor.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Reduce Reliability</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: A parent class has a virtual destructor method, but the parent has a child class that does not have a virtual destructor.
cwe.name: Parent Class with a Virtual Destructor and a Child Class without a Virtual Destructor
cwe.extended_summary: b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7"><html:p>This issue can prevent the product from running reliably, since the child might not perform essential destruction operations.  If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker, then this reliability problem might introduce a vulnerability, such as a memory leak (CWE-401).</html:p></ns0:Extended_Description>\n         '

cwe.description: The product creates an immutable text string using string concatenation operations.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Reduce Performance</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product creates an immutable text string using string concatenation operations.
cwe.name: Creation of Immutable Text Using String Concatenation
cwe.extended_summary: b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7"><html:p>When building a string via a looping feature (e.g., a FOR or WHILE loop), the use of += to append to the existing string will result in the creation of a new object with each iteration. This programming pattern can be inefficient in comparison with use of text buffer data elements. This issue can make the product perform more slowly. If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker, then this could be influenced to create performance problem.</html:p></ns0:Extended_Description>\n         '

cwe.description: The product contains modules in which one module has references that cycle back to itself, i.e., there are circular dependencies.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Reduce Reliability</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product contains modules in which one module has references that cycle back to itself, i.e., there are circular dependencies.
cwe.name: Modules with Circular Dependencies
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7"><html:p>As an example, with Java, this weakness might indicate cycles between packages.</html:p>
<html:p>This issue makes it more difficult to maintain the product due to insufficient modularity, which indirectly affects security by making it more difficult or time-consuming to find and/or fix vulnerabilities.  It also might make it easier to introduce vulnerabilities.</html:p>
<html:p>This issue can prevent the product from running reliably.  If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker, then this reliability problem might introduce a vulnerability.</html:p></ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description:
The code contains callable control elements that
         contain an excessively large number of references to other
         application objects external to the context of the callable,
         i.e. a Fan-Out value that is excessively large.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Reduce Maintainability</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary:
The code contains callable control elements that
         contain an excessively large number of references to other
         application objects external to the context of the callable,
         i.e. a Fan-Out value that is excessively large.
cwe.name: Invokable Control Element with Large Number of Outward Calls
cwe.extended_summary: b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7"><html:p>While the interpretation of "excessively large Fan-Out value" may vary for each product or developer, CISQ recommends a default of 5 referenced objects.</html:p>\n\t\t <html:p>This issue makes it more difficult to maintain the product, which indirectly affects security by making it more difficult or time-consuming to find and/or fix vulnerabilities.  It also might make it easier to introduce vulnerabilities.</html:p></ns0:Extended_Description>\n         '

cwe.description:
The product performs a data query with a large number of joins
					and sub-queries on a large data table.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Reduce Performance</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary:
The product performs a data query with a large number of joins
					and sub-queries on a large data table.
cwe.name: Excessive Data Query Operations in a Large Data Table
cwe.extended_summary: b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7"><html:p>This issue can make the product perform more slowly.  If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker, then this performance problem might introduce a vulnerability.</html:p>\n\t <html:p>While the interpretation of "large data table" and "large number of joins or sub-queries" may vary for each product or developer, CISQ recommends a default of 1 million rows for a "large" data table, a default minimum of 5 joins, and a default minimum of 3 sub-queries.</html:p></ns0:Extended_Description>\n         '

cwe.description: The product has a form field that is not validated by a corresponding validation form, which can introduce other weaknesses related to insufficient input validation.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Unexpected State</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Bypass Protection Mechanism</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>If unused fields are not validated, shared business logic in an action may allow attackers to bypass the validation checks that are performed for other uses of the form.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product has a form field that is not validated by a corresponding validation form, which can introduce other weaknesses related to insufficient input validation.
cwe.name: Struts: Form Field Without Validator
cwe.extended_summary: Omitting validation for even a single input field may give attackers the leeway they need to compromise the product. Although J2EE applications are not generally susceptible to memory corruption attacks, if a J2EE application interfaces with native code that does not perform array bounds checking, an attacker may be able to use an input validation mistake in the J2EE application to launch a buffer overflow attack.

cwe.description:
The product has a loop body or loop condition that contains a control element that directly or
					indirectly consumes platform resources, e.g. messaging, sessions, locks, or file
					descriptors.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">

cwe.summary:
The product has a loop body or loop condition that contains a control element that directly or

					descriptors.

cwe.extended_summary: b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7"><html:p>This issue can make the product perform more slowly.  If an attacker can influence the number of iterations in the loop, then this performance problem might allow a denial of service by consuming more platform resources than intended.</html:p></ns0:Extended_Description>\n         '

cwe.description: The product initializes data using hard-coded values that act as network resource identifiers.

cwe.extended_summary: b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7"><html:p>This issue can prevent the product from running reliably, e.g. if it runs in an environment does not use the hard-coded network resource identifiers. If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker, then this reliability problem might introduce a vulnerability.</html:p></ns0:Extended_Description>\n         '

The product initializes a data element using a hard-coded

The product initializes a data element using a hard-coded

cwe.extended_summary: b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7"><html:p>This issue makes it more difficult to modify or maintain the product, which indirectly affects security by making it more difficult or time-consuming to find and/or fix vulnerabilities.  It also might make it easier to introduce vulnerabilities.</html:p></ns0:Extended_Description>\n         '

cwe.description: The product does not have documentation that represents how it is designed.

It can make it more difficult and time-consuming to detect and/or fix vulnerabilities.</html:p></ns0:Extended_Description>\n         '

cwe.summary:
The code at one architectural layer invokes code that resides

					layer, and the invoked code is not part of a vertical utility layer that can be referenced from any horizontal layer.

cwe.extended_summary: b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7"><html:p>This issue makes it more difficult to understand and maintain the product, which indirectly affects security by making it more difficult or time-consuming to find and/or fix vulnerabilities.  It also might make it easier to introduce vulnerabilities.</html:p></ns0:Extended_Description>\n         '

The product contains a class with inheritance from more than

It also might make it easier to introduce vulnerabilities.</html:p></ns0:Extended_Description>\n         '

cwe.description:
A named-callable or method control element has a signature that
					supports a variable (variadic) number of parameters or arguments.

b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">

cwe.summary:
A named-callable or method control element has a signature that
					supports a variable (variadic) number of parameters or arguments.
cwe.name: Invokable Control Element with Variadic Parameters
cwe.extended_summary: b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7"><html:p>This issue can prevent the product from running reliably.  If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker, then this reliability problem might introduce a vulnerability.</html:p>\n\t\t <html:p>With variadic arguments, it can be difficult or inefficient for manual analysis to be certain of which function/method is being invoked.</html:p></ns0:Extended_Description>\n         '

cwe.description: The product uses a dedicated, central data manager component as required by design, but it contains code that performs data-access operations that do not use this data manager.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Reduce Performance</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product uses a dedicated, central data manager component as required by design, but it contains code that performs data-access operations that do not use this data manager.
cwe.name: Data Access Operations Outside of Expected Data Manager Component
cwe.extended_summary: b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7"><html:p>This issue can make the product perform more slowly than intended, since the intended central data manager may have been explicitly optimized for performance or other quality characteristics.  If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker, then this performance problem might introduce a vulnerability.</html:p></ns0:Extended_Description>\n         '

cwe.description:
The code contains a function or method that
		 operates in a multi-threaded environment but owns an unsafe non-final
		                     static storable or member data element.

b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">

cwe.extended_summary: b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7"><html:p>This issue can prevent the product from running reliably.  If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker, then this reliability problem might introduce a vulnerability.</html:p></ns0:Extended_Description>\n         '

cwe.description:
The product does not contain sufficient
         technical or engineering documentation (whether on paper or
         in electronic form) that contains descriptions of all the
         relevant software/hardware elements of the product, such as
         its usage, structure, architectural components, interfaces, design, implementation,
         configuration, operation, etc.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Varies by Context</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Hide Activities</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Reduce Reliability</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Quality Degradation</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Reduce Maintainability</ns0:Impact>
	       <ns0:Note>Without a method of verification, one cannot be sure that everything only functions as expected.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary:
The product does not contain sufficient
         technical or engineering documentation (whether on paper or
         in electronic form) that contains descriptions of all the
         relevant software/hardware elements of the product, such as
         its usage, structure, architectural components, interfaces, design, implementation,
         configuration, operation, etc.
cwe.name: Insufficient Technical Documentation
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
	   <html:p>When technical documentation is limited or lacking, products are more difficult to maintain.  This indirectly affects security by making it more difficult or time-consuming to find and/or fix vulnerabilities.</html:p>
	 <html:p>When using time-limited or labor-limited third-party/in-house security consulting services (such as threat modeling, vulnerability discovery, or pentesting), insufficient documentation can force those consultants to invest unnecessary time in learning how the product is organized, instead of focusing their expertise on finding the flaws or suggesting effective mitigations.</html:p>
	 <html:p>With respect to hardware design, the lack of a formal, final manufacturer reference can make it difficult or impossible to evaluate the final product, including post-manufacture verification. One cannot ensure that design functionality or operation is within acceptable tolerances, conforms to specifications, and is free from unexpected behavior. Hardware-related documentation may include engineering artifacts such as hardware description language (HDLs), netlists, Gerber files, Bills of Materials, EDA (Electronic Design Automation) tool files, etc.</html:p>
	 </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: When an application does not use an input validation framework such as the Struts Validator, there is a greater risk of introducing weaknesses related to insufficient input validation.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Unexpected State</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: When an application does not use an input validation framework such as the Struts Validator, there is a greater risk of introducing weaknesses related to insufficient input validation.
cwe.name: Struts: Plug-in Framework not in Use
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <html:p>Unchecked input is the leading cause of vulnerabilities in J2EE applications. Unchecked input leads to cross-site scripting, process control, and SQL injection vulnerabilities, among others.</html:p>
            <html:p>Although J2EE applications are not generally susceptible to memory corruption attacks, if a J2EE application interfaces with native code that does not perform array bounds checking, an attacker may be able to use an input validation mistake in the J2EE application to launch a buffer overflow attack.</html:p>
         </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: The product performs too many data queries without using efficient data processing functionality such as stored procedures.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Reduce Performance</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product performs too many data queries without using efficient data processing functionality such as stored procedures.
cwe.name: Excessive Number of Inefficient Server-Side Data Accesses
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7"><html:p>This issue can make the product perform more slowly due to computational expense.  If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker, then this performance problem might introduce a vulnerability.</html:p>
	 <html:p>While the interpretation of "too many data queries" may vary for each product or developer, CISQ recommends a default maximum of 5 data queries for an inefficient function/procedure.</html:p>
	 </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: The product does not sufficiently hide the internal representation and implementation details of data or methods, which might allow external components or modules to modify data unexpectedly, invoke unexpected functionality, or introduce dependencies that the programmer did not intend.

cwe.name: Insufficient Encapsulation
cwe.extended_summary: b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7"><html:p>This issue makes it more difficult to maintain the product, which indirectly affects security by making it more difficult or time-consuming to find and/or fix vulnerabilities.  It also might make it easier to introduce vulnerabilities.</html:p></ns0:Extended_Description>\n         '

cwe.description: The code has a parent class that contains references to a child class, its methods, or its members.

cwe.extended_summary: b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7"><html:p>This issue can prevent the product from running reliably.  If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker, then this reliability problem might introduce a vulnerability.</html:p></ns0:Extended_Description>\n         '

cwe.description: A static code block creates an instance of a class.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>

            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: A static code block creates an instance of a class.
cwe.name: Creation of Class Instance within a Static Code Block
cwe.extended_summary: b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7"><html:p>This pattern identifies situations where a storable data element or member data element is initialized with a value in a block of code which is declared as static.</html:p>\n<html:p>This issue can make the product perform more slowly by performing initialization before it is needed.  If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker, then this performance problem might introduce a vulnerability.</html:p></ns0:Extended_Description>\n         '

cwe.description:
The product contains a function, subroutine, or method whose signature has an unnecessarily large number of
					parameters/arguments.

The product contains a function, subroutine, or method whose signature has an unnecessarily large number of

It also might make it easier to introduce vulnerabilities.</html:p>\n\t <html:p>While the interpretation of "large number of parameters." may vary for each product or developer, CISQ recommends a default maximum of 7 parameters/arguments.</html:p></ns0:Extended_Description>\n         '

cwe.extended_summary: b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7"><html:p>This issue can prevent the product from running reliably.  If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker, then this reliability problem might introduce a vulnerability.</html:p></ns0:Extended_Description>\n         '

cwe.description:
The product contains a serializable data element that does not

b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">

cwe.summary:
The product contains a serializable data element that does not

cwe.extended_summary: b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7"><html:p>This issue can prevent the product from running reliably, e.g. by triggering an exception.  If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker, then this reliability problem might introduce a vulnerability.</html:p>\n\t <html:p>As examples, the serializable nature of a data element comes from a serializable SerializableAttribute attribute in .NET and the inheritance from the java.io.Serializable interface in Java.</html:p></ns0:Extended_Description>\n         '

					that is configured in a way that does not utilize an index and may cause

cwe.extended_summary: b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7"><html:p>This issue can make the product perform more slowly.  If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker, then this performance problem might introduce a vulnerability.</html:p></ns0:Extended_Description>\n         '

cwe.extended_summary: b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7"><html:p>This issue makes it more difficult to maintain the product due to inconsistencies, which indirectly affects security by making it more difficult or time-consuming to find and/or fix vulnerabilities.  It also might make it easier to introduce vulnerabilities.</html:p></ns0:Extended_Description>\n         '

cwe.description: An invokable code block contains an exception handling block that does not contain any code, i.e. is empty.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>

If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker, then this reliability problem might introduce a vulnerability.</html:p></ns0:Extended_Description>\n         '

cwe.description: An unused validation form indicates that validation logic is not up-to-date.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Quality Degradation</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: An unused validation form indicates that validation logic is not up-to-date.
cwe.name: Struts: Unused Validation Form
cwe.extended_summary: It is easy for developers to forget to update validation logic when they remove or rename action form mappings. One indication that validation logic is not being properly maintained is the presence of an unused validation form.

cwe.description:
The product contains a serializable, storable data element such as a field or member,
					but the data element contains member elements that are not
					serializable.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Reduce Reliability</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary:
The product contains a serializable, storable data element such as a field or member,
					but the data element contains member elements that are not
					serializable.
cwe.name: Serializable Data Element Containing non-Serializable Item Elements
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7"><html:p>This issue can prevent the product from running reliably.  If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker, then this reliability problem might introduce a vulnerability.</html:p>
 	 <html:p>As examples, the serializable nature of a data element comes from a serializable SerializableAttribute attribute in .NET and the inheritance from the java.io.Serializable interface in Java.</html:p>
	 </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: The source code contains a block that does not contain any code, i.e., the block is empty.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Reduce Reliability</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The source code contains a block that does not contain any code, i.e., the block is empty.
cwe.name: Empty Code Block
cwe.extended_summary: b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7"><html:p>Empty code blocks can occur in the bodies of conditionals, function or method definitions, exception handlers, etc.  While an empty code block might be intentional, it might also indicate incomplete implementation, accidental code deletion, unexpected macro expansion, etc.  For some programming languages and constructs, an empty block might be allowed by the syntax, but the lack of any behavior within the block might violate a convention or API in such a way that it is an error.</html:p>\n\t </ns0:Extended_Description>\n         '

cwe.description:
The product accesses a data resource through a database without using a
					connection pooling capability.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Reduce Performance</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary:
The product accesses a data resource through a database without using a
					connection pooling capability.
cwe.name: Data Resource Access without Use of Connection Pooling
cwe.extended_summary: b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7"><html:p>This issue can make the product perform more slowly, as connection pools allow connections to be reused without the overhead and time consumption of opening and closing a new connection.  If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker, then this performance problem might introduce a vulnerability.</html:p></ns0:Extended_Description>\n         '

cwe.description: The product contains a client with a function or method that contains a large number of data accesses/queries that are sent through a data manager, i.e., does not use efficient database capabilities.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>

cwe.summary: The product contains a client with a function or method that contains a large number of data accesses/queries that are sent through a data manager, i.e., does not use efficient database capabilities.
cwe.name: Non-SQL Invokable Control Element with Excessive Number of Data Resource Accesses
cwe.extended_summary: b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7"><html:p>This issue can make the product perform more slowly.  If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker, then this performance problem might introduce a vulnerability.</html:p>\n\t <html:p>While the interpretation of "large number of data accesses/queries" may vary for each product or developer, CISQ recommends a default maximum of 2 data accesses per function/method.</html:p></ns0:Extended_Description>\n         '

cwe.description:
A class has an inheritance level that is too high, i.e., it

cwe.summary:
A class has an inheritance level that is too high, i.e., it
					has a large number of parent classes.
cwe.name: Class with Excessively Deep Inheritance
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7"><html:p>This issue makes it more difficult to understand and maintain the product, which indirectly affects security by making it more difficult or time-consuming to find and/or fix vulnerabilities.  It also might make it easier to introduce vulnerabilities.</html:p>
	 <html:p>While the interpretation of "large number of parent classes" may vary for each product or developer, CISQ recommends a default maximum of 7 parent classes.</html:p>
	 </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

It also might make it easier to introduce vulnerabilities.</html:p></ns0:Extended_Description>\n         '

cwe.description:
The code performs a comparison such as an
        equality test between two float (floating point) values, but
        it uses comparison operators that do not account for the
        possibility of loss of precision.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Reduce Reliability</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary:
The code performs a comparison such as an
        equality test between two float (floating point) values, but
        it uses comparison operators that do not account for the
        possibility of loss of precision.
cwe.name: Floating Point Comparison with Incorrect Operator
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
	   <html:p>Numeric calculation using floating point values
	   can generate imprecise results because of rounding errors.
	   As a result, two different calculations might generate
	   numbers that are mathematically equal, but have slightly
	   different bit representations that do not translate to the
	   same mathematically-equal values.  As a result, an equality
	   test or other comparison might produce unexpected
	   results.</html:p>
	   <html:p>This issue can prevent the product from running reliably.  If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker, then this reliability problem might introduce a vulnerability.</html:p></ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description:
The source code does not follow
				desired style or formatting for indentation, white
				space, comments, etc.
cwe.summary:
The source code does not follow
				desired style or formatting for indentation, white
				space, comments, etc.
cwe.name: Inappropriate Source Code Style or Formatting

cwe.description: A parent class contains one or more child classes, but the parent class does not have a virtual destructor method.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Reduce Reliability</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: A parent class contains one or more child classes, but the parent class does not have a virtual destructor method.
cwe.name: Parent Class without Virtual Destructor Method
cwe.extended_summary: b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7"><html:p>This issue can prevent the product from running reliably due to undefined or unexpected behaviors.  If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker, then this reliability problem might introduce a vulnerability.</html:p></ns0:Extended_Description>\n         '

cwe.description: Every Action Form must have a corresponding validation form.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Other</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>If an action form mapping does not have a validation form defined, it may be vulnerable to a number of attacks that rely on unchecked input. Unchecked input is the root cause of some of today's worst and most common software security problems. Cross-site scripting, SQL injection, and process control vulnerabilities all stem from incomplete or absent input validation.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Other</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>Although J2EE applications are not generally susceptible to memory corruption attacks, if a J2EE application interfaces with native code that does not perform array bounds checking, an attacker may be able to use an input validation mistake in the J2EE application to launch a buffer overflow attack.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: Every Action Form must have a corresponding validation form.
cwe.name: Struts: Unvalidated Action Form
cwe.extended_summary: If a Struts Action Form Mapping specifies a form, it must have a validation form defined under the Struts Validator.

cwe.description:
A source code file has too many lines of
					code.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Reduce Maintainability</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary:
A source code file has too many lines of
					code.
cwe.name: Source Code File with Excessive Number of Lines of Code
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7"><html:p>This issue makes it more difficult to understand and/or maintain the product, which indirectly affects security by making it more difficult or time-consuming to find and/or fix vulnerabilities.  It also might make it easier to introduce vulnerabilities.</html:p>
		 <html:p>While the interpretation of "too many lines of code" may vary for each product or developer, CISQ recommends a default threshold value of 1000.</html:p>
		 </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: The code contains a class instance that calls the method or function to delete or destroy itself.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">

cwe.summary: The code contains a class instance that calls the method or function to delete or destroy itself.
cwe.name: Class Instance Self Destruction Control Element
cwe.extended_summary: b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7"><html:p>For example, in C++, "delete this" will cause the object to delete itself.</html:p>\n\t <html:p>This issue can prevent the product from running reliably.  If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker, then this reliability problem might introduce a vulnerability.</html:p></ns0:Extended_Description>\n         '

cwe.description: The product is intended to manage data access through a particular data manager component such as a relational or non-SQL database, but it contains code that performs data access operations without using that component.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>

            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product is intended to manage data access through a particular data manager component such as a relational or non-SQL database, but it contains code that performs data access operations without using that component.
cwe.name: Data Access from Outside Expected Data Manager Component
cwe.extended_summary: b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7"><html:p>When the product has a data access component, the design may be intended to handle all data access operations through that component.  If a data access operation is performed outside of that component, then this may indicate a violation of the intended design.</html:p>\n\t <html:p>This issue can prevent the product from running reliably.  If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker, then this reliability problem might introduce a vulnerability.</html:p></ns0:Extended_Description>\n         '

It also might make it easier to introduce vulnerabilities.</html:p>\n\t <html:p>While the interpretation of "too many operations" may vary for each product or developer, CISQ recommends a default maximum of 7 operations for the same data manager or file.</html:p></ns0:Extended_Description>\n         '

cwe.description: Debugging messages help attackers learn about the system and plan a form of attack.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>Attackers can leverage the additional information they gain from debugging output to mount attacks targeted on the framework, database, or other resources used by the application.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: Debugging messages help attackers learn about the system and plan a form of attack.
cwe.name: ASP.NET Misconfiguration: Creating Debug Binary
cwe.extended_summary: ASP .NET applications can be configured to produce debug binaries. These binaries give detailed debugging messages and should not be used in production environments. Debug binaries are meant to be used in a development or testing environment and can pose a security risk if they are deployed to production.

cwe.description: Validation fields that do not appear in forms they are associated with indicate that the validation logic is out of date.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Other</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>It is critically important that validation logic be maintained and kept in sync with the rest of the application. Unchecked input is the root cause of some of today's worst and most common software security problems. Cross-site scripting, SQL injection, and process control vulnerabilities all stem from incomplete or absent input validation.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: Validation fields that do not appear in forms they are associated with indicate that the validation logic is out of date.
cwe.name: Struts: Validator Without Form Field
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <html:p>It is easy for developers to forget to update validation logic when they make changes to an ActionForm class. One indication that validation logic is not being properly maintained is inconsistencies between the action form and the validation form.</html:p>
            <html:p>Although J2EE applications are not generally susceptible to memory corruption attacks, if a J2EE application interfaces with native code that does not perform array bounds checking, an attacker may be able to use an input validation mistake in the J2EE application to launch a buffer overflow attack.</html:p>
         </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: When a Java application uses the Java Native Interface (JNI) to call code written in another programming language, it can expose the application to weaknesses in that code, even if those weaknesses cannot occur in Java.
cwe.common_consequences:

cwe.summary: When a Java application uses the Java Native Interface (JNI) to call code written in another programming language, it can expose the application to weaknesses in that code, even if those weaknesses cannot occur in Java.
cwe.name: Direct Use of Unsafe JNI
cwe.extended_summary: Many safety features that programmers may take for granted do not apply for native code, so you must carefully review all such code for potential problems. The languages used to implement native code may be more susceptible to buffer overflows and other attacks. Native code is unprotected by the security features enforced by the runtime environment, such as strong typing and array bounds checking.

cwe.extended_summary: b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7"><html:p>Originating from software security, an "attack surface" measure typically reflects the number of input points and output points that can be utilized by an untrusted party, i.e. a potential attacker. A larger attack surface provides more places to attack, and more opportunities for developers to introduce weaknesses.  In some cases, this measure may reflect other aspects of quality besides security; e.g., a product with many inputs and outputs may require a large number of tests in order to improve code coverage.</html:p></ns0:Extended_Description>\n         '

cwe.description: The product receives data from an HTTP agent/component (e.g., web server, proxy, browser, etc.), but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes CR and LF characters before the data is included in outgoing HTTP headers.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>CR and LF characters in an HTTP header may give attackers control of the remaining headers and body of the message that the application intends to send/receive, as well as allowing them to create additional messages entirely under their control.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product receives data from an HTTP agent/component (e.g., web server, proxy, browser, etc.), but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes CR and LF characters before the data is included in outgoing HTTP headers.
cwe.name: Improper Neutralization of CRLF Sequences in HTTP Headers ('HTTP Request/Response Splitting')
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
	   <html:p>
	     HTTP agents or components may include a web server, load balancer, reverse proxy, web caching proxy, application firewall, web browser, etc. Regardless of the role, they are expected to maintain coherent, consistent HTTP communication state across all components. However, including unexpected data in an HTTP header allows an attacker to specify the entirety of the HTTP message that is rendered by the client HTTP agent (e.g., web browser) or back-end HTTP agent (e.g., web server), whether the message is part of a request or a response.
	   </html:p>
            <html:p>When an HTTP request contains unexpected CR and LF characters, the server may respond with an output stream that is interpreted as "splitting" the stream into two different HTTP messages instead of one. CR is carriage return, also given by %0d or \r, and LF is line feed, also given by %0a or \n.</html:p>
	    <html:p>In addition to CR and LF characters, other valid/RFC compliant special characters and unique character encodings can be utilized, such as HT (horizontal tab, also given by %09 or \t) and SP (space, also given as + sign or %20).</html:p>
	    <html:p>These types of unvalidated and unexpected data in HTTP message headers allow an attacker to control the second "split" message to mount attacks such as server-side request forgery, cross-site scripting, and cache poisoning attacks.</html:p>
            <html:p>HTTP response splitting weaknesses may be present when:</html:p>
               <html:ol>
                  <html:li>Data enters a web application through an untrusted source, most frequently an HTTP request.</html:li>
                  <html:li>The data is included in an HTTP response header sent to a web user without neutralizing malicious characters that can be interpreted as separator characters for headers.</html:li>
               </html:ol>
         </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: Executing commands or loading libraries from an untrusted source or in an untrusted environment can cause an application to execute malicious commands (and payloads) on behalf of an attacker.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Execute Unauthorized Code or Commands</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: Executing commands or loading libraries from an untrusted source or in an untrusted environment can cause an application to execute malicious commands (and payloads) on behalf of an attacker.
cwe.name: Process Control
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">Process control vulnerabilities take two forms:
	 <html:ul>
	   <html:li>An attacker can change the command that the program executes: the attacker explicitly controls what the command is.</html:li>
	   <html:li>An attacker can change the environment in which the command executes: the attacker implicitly controls what the command means.</html:li>
	 </html:ul>
	 <html:p>Process control vulnerabilities of the first type occur when either data enters the application from an untrusted source and the data is used as part of a string representing a command that is executed by the application. By executing the command, the application gives an attacker a privilege or capability that the attacker would not otherwise have.</html:p>
	 </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: The product misinterprets an input, whether from an attacker or another product, in a security-relevant fashion.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Unexpected State</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product misinterprets an input, whether from an attacker or another product, in a security-relevant fashion.
cwe.name: Misinterpretation of Input

cwe.description: The product prepares a structured message for communication with another component, but encoding or escaping of the data is either missing or done incorrectly. As a result, the intended structure of the message is not preserved.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>The communications between components can be modified in unexpected ways. Unexpected commands can be executed, bypassing other security mechanisms. Incoming data can be misinterpreted.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Execute Unauthorized Code or Commands</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>The communications between components can be modified in unexpected ways. Unexpected commands can be executed, bypassing other security mechanisms. Incoming data can be misinterpreted.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Bypass Protection Mechanism</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>The communications between components can be modified in unexpected ways. Unexpected commands can be executed, bypassing other security mechanisms. Incoming data can be misinterpreted.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product prepares a structured message for communication with another component, but encoding or escaping of the data is either missing or done incorrectly. As a result, the intended structure of the message is not preserved.
cwe.name: Improper Encoding or Escaping of Output
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <html:p>Improper encoding or escaping can allow attackers to change the commands that are sent to another component, inserting malicious commands instead.</html:p>
            <html:p>Most products follow a certain protocol that uses structured messages for communication between components, such as queries or commands. These structured messages can contain raw data interspersed with metadata or control information. For example, "GET /index.html HTTP/1.1" is a structured message containing a command ("GET") with a single argument ("/index.html") and metadata about which protocol version is being used ("HTTP/1.1").</html:p>
            <html:p>If an application uses attacker-supplied inputs to construct a structured message without properly encoding or escaping, then the attacker could insert special characters that will cause the data to be interpreted as control information or metadata. Consequently, the component that receives the output will perform the wrong operations, or otherwise interpret the data incorrectly.</html:p>
         </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description:
The product contains code that is not essential for execution,
