cwe.description: The product releases a resource such as memory or a file so that it can be made available for reuse, but it does not clear or "zeroize" the information contained in the resource before the product performs a critical state transition or makes the resource available for reuse by other entities.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
      <ns0:Consequence>
        <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
        <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
      </ns0:Consequence>
     </ns0:Common_Consequences>
     '
cwe.summary: The product releases a resource such as memory or a file so that it can be made available for reuse, but it does not clear or "zeroize" the information contained in the resource before the product performs a critical state transition or makes the resource available for reuse by other entities.
cwe.name: Sensitive Information in Resource Not Removed Before Reuse
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
			 <html:p>When resources are released, they can be made available for reuse. For example, after memory is de-allocated, an operating system may make the memory available to another process, or disk space may be reallocated when a file is deleted. As removing information requires time and additional resources, operating systems do not usually clear the previously written information.</html:p>
			 <html:p>Even when the resource is reused by the same process, this weakness can arise when new data is not as large as the old data, which leaves portions of the old data still available. Equivalent errors can occur in other situations where the length of data is variable but the associated data structure is not. If memory is not cleared after use, the information may be read by less trustworthy parties when the memory is reallocated.</html:p>
			 <html:p>This weakness can apply in hardware, such as when a device or system switches between power, sleep, or debug states during normal operation, or when execution changes to different users or privilege levels.</html:p>
     </ns0:Extended_Description>
     '

cwe.description: The product does not handle or incorrectly handles input that is not syntactically well-formed with respect to the associated specification.

               <ns0:Impact>DoS: Crash, Exit, or Restart</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>DoS: Resource Consumption (CPU)</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>If an input is syntactically invalid, then processing the input could place the system in an unexpected state that could lead to a crash, consume available system resources or other unintended behaviors.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>

b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Unexpected State</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product does not handle or incorrectly handles when a particular structural element is not completely specified.
cwe.name: Improper Handling of Incomplete Structural Elements

cwe.description: The product does not properly handle when a particular element is not completely specified.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Varies by Context</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Unexpected State</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product does not properly handle when a particular element is not completely specified.
cwe.name: Failure to Handle Incomplete Element

cwe.description: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize "../" sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize "../" sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.
cwe.name: Path Traversal: '../filedir'
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <html:p>This allows attackers to traverse the file system to access files or directories that are outside of the restricted directory.</html:p>
            <html:p>The "../" manipulation is the canonical manipulation for operating systems that use "/" as directory separators, such as UNIX- and Linux-based systems. In some cases, it is useful for bypassing protection schemes in environments for which "/" is supported but not the primary separator, such as Windows, which uses "\" but can also accept "/".</html:p>
         </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: The product does not handle or incorrectly handles when two or more structural elements should be consistent, but are not.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Varies by Context</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Unexpected State</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product does not handle or incorrectly handles when two or more structural elements should be consistent, but are not.
cwe.name: Improper Handling of Inconsistent Structural Elements

cwe.description: The product does not handle or incorrectly handles when a particular element is not the expected type, e.g. it expects a digit (0-9) but is provided with a letter (A-Z).
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>

               <ns0:Impact>Varies by Context</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Unexpected State</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product does not handle or incorrectly handles when a particular element is not the expected type, e.g. it expects a digit (0-9) but is provided with a letter (A-Z).
cwe.name: Improper Handling of Unexpected Data Type

cwe.description: The product calls a function that can never be guaranteed to work safely.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Varies by Context</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product calls a function that can never be guaranteed to work safely.
cwe.name: Use of Inherently Dangerous Function
cwe.extended_summary: Certain functions behave in dangerous ways regardless of how they are used. Functions in this category were often implemented without taking security concerns into account. The gets() function is unsafe because it does not perform bounds checking on the size of its input. An attacker can easily send arbitrarily-sized input to gets() and overflow the destination buffer. Similarly, the >> operator is unsafe to use when reading into a statically-allocated character array because it does not perform bounds checking on the size of its input. An attacker can easily send arbitrarily-sized input to the >> operator and overflow the destination buffer.

cwe.description: The product uses the chroot() system call to create a jail, but does not change the working directory afterward. This does not prevent access to files outside of the jail.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product uses the chroot() system call to create a jail, but does not change the working directory afterward. This does not prevent access to files outside of the jail.
cwe.name: Creation of chroot Jail Without Changing Working Directory
cwe.extended_summary: Improper use of chroot() may allow attackers to escape from the chroot jail. The chroot() function call does not change the process's current working directory, so relative paths may still refer to file system resources outside of the chroot jail after chroot() has been called.

cwe.description: Using realloc() to resize buffers that store sensitive information can leave the sensitive information exposed to attack, because it is not removed from memory.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Memory</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Other</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>Be careful using vfork() and fork() in security sensitive code. The process state will not be cleaned up and will contain traces of data from past use.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: Using realloc() to resize buffers that store sensitive information can leave the sensitive information exposed to attack, because it is not removed from memory.
cwe.name: Improper Clearing of Heap Memory Before Release ('Heap Inspection')
cwe.extended_summary: When sensitive data such as a password or an encryption key is not removed from memory, it could be exposed to an attacker using a "heap inspection" attack that reads the sensitive data using memory dumps or other methods. The realloc() function is commonly used to increase the size of a block of allocated memory. This operation often requires copying the contents of the old memory block into a new and larger block. This operation leaves the contents of the original block intact but inaccessible to the program, preventing the program from being able to scrub sensitive data from memory. If an attacker can later examine the contents of a memory dump, the sensitive data could be exposed.

cwe.description: The J2EE application directly manages connections, instead of using the container's connection management facilities.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Quality Degradation</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The J2EE application directly manages connections, instead of using the container's connection management facilities.
cwe.name: J2EE Bad Practices: Direct Management of Connections
cwe.extended_summary: The J2EE standard forbids the direct management of connections. It requires that applications use the container's resource management facilities to obtain connections to resources. Every major web application container provides pooled database connection management as part of its resource management framework. Duplicating this functionality in an application is difficult and error prone, which is part of the reason it is forbidden under the J2EE standard.

cwe.description: The J2EE application directly uses sockets instead of using framework method calls.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Quality Degradation</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The J2EE application directly uses sockets instead of using framework method calls.
cwe.name: J2EE Bad Practices: Direct Use of Sockets
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <html:p>The J2EE standard permits the use of sockets only for the purpose of communication with legacy systems when no higher-level protocol is available. Authoring your own communication protocol requires wrestling with difficult security issues.</html:p>
            <html:p>Without significant scrutiny by a security expert, chances are good that a custom communication protocol will suffer from security problems. Many of the same issues apply to a custom implementation of a standard protocol. While there are usually more resources available that address security concerns related to implementing a standard protocol, these resources are also available to attackers.</html:p>
         </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: This entry has been deprecated because it was a duplicate of CWE-350. All content has been transferred to CWE-350.
cwe.summary: This entry has been deprecated because it was a duplicate of CWE-350. All content has been transferred to CWE-350.
cwe.name: DEPRECATED: Reliance on DNS Lookups in a Security Decision

cwe.description: An exception is thrown from a function, but it is not caught.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>DoS: Crash, Exit, or Restart</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>An uncaught exception could cause the system to be placed in a state that could lead to a crash, exposure of sensitive information or other unintended behaviors.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: An exception is thrown from a function, but it is not caught.
cwe.name: Uncaught Exception
cwe.extended_summary: When an exception is not caught, it may cause the program to crash or expose sensitive information.

cwe.description:
This entry has been deprecated because of name
	confusion and an accidental combination of multiple
	weaknesses. Most of its content has been transferred to
	CWE-785.
cwe.summary:
This entry has been deprecated because of name
	confusion and an accidental combination of multiple
	weaknesses. Most of its content has been transferred to
	CWE-785.
cwe.name: DEPRECATED: Often Misused: Path Manipulation
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
        <html:p>This entry was deprecated for several reasons. The primary
        reason is over-loading of the "path manipulation" term and the
        description. The original description for this entry was the
        same as that for the "Often Misused: File System" item in the
        original Seven Pernicious Kingdoms paper. However, Seven
        Pernicious Kingdoms also has a "Path Manipulation" phrase that
        is for external control of pathnames (CWE-73), which is a
        factor in symbolic link following and path traversal, neither
        of which is explicitly mentioned in 7PK. Fortify uses the
        phrase "Often Misused: Path Manipulation" for a broader range
        of problems, generally for issues related to buffer
        management. Given the multiple conflicting uses of this term,
        there is a chance that CWE users may have incorrectly mapped
        to this entry.</html:p>

	<html:p>The second reason for deprecation is an implied combination of
	multiple weaknesses within buffer-handling functions. The
	focus of this entry was generally on the path-conversion
	functions and their association with buffer
	overflows. However, some of Fortify's Vulncat entries have the
	term "path manipulation" but describe a non-overflow weakness
	in which the buffer is not guaranteed to contain the entire
	pathname, i.e., there is information truncation (see CWE-222
	for a similar concept). A new entry for this non-overflow
	weakness may be created in a future version of CWE.</html:p>
	</ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize "/../" sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize "/../" sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.
cwe.name: Path Traversal: '/../filedir'
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <html:p>This allows attackers to traverse the file system to access files or directories that are outside of the restricted directory.</html:p>
            <html:p>Sometimes a program checks for "../" at the beginning of the input, so a "/../" can bypass that check.</html:p>
         </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: The product performs an operation at a privilege level that is higher than the minimum level required, which creates new weaknesses or amplifies the consequences of other weaknesses.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Execute Unauthorized Code or Commands</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>DoS: Crash, Exit, or Restart</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>An attacker will be able to gain access to any resources that are allowed by the extra privileges. Common results include executing code, disabling services, and reading restricted data.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product performs an operation at a privilege level that is higher than the minimum level required, which creates new weaknesses or amplifies the consequences of other weaknesses.
cwe.name: Execution with Unnecessary Privileges
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <html:p>New weaknesses can be exposed because running with extra privileges, such as root or Administrator, can disable the normal security checks being performed by the operating system or surrounding environment. Other pre-existing weaknesses can turn into security vulnerabilities if they occur while operating at raised privileges.</html:p>
            <html:p>Privilege management functions can behave in some less-than-obvious ways, and they have different quirks on different platforms. These inconsistencies are particularly pronounced if you are transitioning from one non-root user to another. Signal handlers and spawned processes run at the privilege of the owning process, so if a process is running as root when a signal fires or a sub-process is executed, the signal handler or sub-process will operate with root privileges.</html:p>
         </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: The product does not check the return value from a method or function, which can prevent it from detecting unexpected states and conditions.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Unexpected State</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>DoS: Crash, Exit, or Restart</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>An unexpected return value could place the system in a state that could lead to a crash or other unintended behaviors.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product does not check the return value from a method or function, which can prevent it from detecting unexpected states and conditions.
cwe.name: Unchecked Return Value
cwe.extended_summary: Two common programmer assumptions are "this function call can never fail" and "it doesn't matter if this function call fails". If an attacker can force the function to fail or otherwise return a value that is not expected, then the subsequent program logic could lead to a vulnerability, because the product is not in a state that the programmer assumes. For example, if the program calls a function to drop privileges but does not check the return code to ensure that privileges were successfully dropped, then the program will continue to operate with the higher privileges.

cwe.description: The product incorrectly checks a return value from a function, which prevents it from detecting errors or exceptional conditions.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Unexpected State</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>DoS: Crash, Exit, or Restart</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>An unexpected return value could place the system in a state that could lead to a crash or other unintended behaviors.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product incorrectly checks a return value from a function, which prevents it from detecting errors or exceptional conditions.
cwe.name: Incorrect Check of Function Return Value
cwe.extended_summary: Important and common functions will return some value about the success of its actions. This will alert the program whether or not to handle any errors caused by that function.

cwe.description: Storing a password in plaintext may result in a system compromise.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: Storing a password in plaintext may result in a system compromise.
cwe.name: Plaintext Storage of a Password
cwe.extended_summary: Password management issues occur when a password is stored in plaintext in an application's properties, configuration file, or memory. Storing a plaintext password in a configuration file allows anyone who can read the file access to the password-protected resource. In some contexts, even storage of a plaintext password in memory is considered a security risk if the password is not cleared immediately after it is used.

cwe.description: The storage of passwords in a recoverable format makes them subject to password reuse attacks by malicious users. In fact, it should be noted that recoverable encrypted passwords provide no significant benefit over plaintext passwords since they are subject not only to reuse by malicious attackers but also by malicious insiders. If a system administrator can recover a password directly, or use a brute force search on the available information, the administrator can use the password on other accounts.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>User's passwords may be revealed.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>Revealed passwords may be reused elsewhere to impersonate the users in question.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The storage of passwords in a recoverable format makes them subject to password reuse attacks by malicious users. In fact, it should be noted that recoverable encrypted passwords provide no significant benefit over plaintext passwords since they are subject not only to reuse by malicious attackers but also by malicious insiders. If a system administrator can recover a password directly, or use a brute force search on the available information, the administrator can use the password on other accounts.
cwe.name: Storing Passwords in a Recoverable Format

cwe.description: Using an empty string as a password is insecure.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: Using an empty string as a password is insecure.
cwe.name: Empty Password in Configuration File

cwe.description: The product contains a hard-coded password, which it uses for its own inbound authentication or for outbound communication to external components.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>If hard-coded passwords are used, it is almost certain that malicious users will gain access through the account in question.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product contains a hard-coded password, which it uses for its own inbound authentication or for outbound communication to external components.
cwe.name: Use of Hard-coded Password
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <html:p>A hard-coded password typically leads to a significant authentication failure that can be difficult for the system administrator to detect. Once detected, it can be difficult to fix, so the administrator may be forced into disabling the product entirely. There are two main variations:</html:p>
            <html:div style="margin-left:1em;">
               <html:div>Inbound: the product contains an authentication mechanism that checks for a hard-coded password.</html:div>
               <html:div>Outbound: the product connects to another system or component, and it contains hard-coded password for connecting to that component.</html:div>
            </html:div>
            <html:p>In the Inbound variant, a default administration account is created, and a simple password is hard-coded into the product and associated with that account. This hard-coded password is the same for each installation of the product, and it usually cannot be changed or disabled by system administrators without manually modifying the program, or otherwise patching the product. If the password is ever discovered or published (a common occurrence on the Internet), then anybody with knowledge of this password can access the product. Finally, since all installations of the product will have the same password, even across different organizations, this enables massive attacks such as worms to take place.</html:p>
            <html:p>The Outbound variant applies to front-end systems that authenticate with a back-end service. The back-end service may require a fixed password which can be easily discovered. The programmer may simply hard-code those back-end credentials into the front-end product. Any user of that program may be able to extract the password. Client-side systems with hard-coded passwords pose even more of a threat, since the extraction of a password from a binary is usually very simple.</html:p>
         </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize "/dir/../filename" sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize "/dir/../filename" sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.
cwe.name: Path Traversal: '/dir/../filename'
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <html:p>This allows attackers to traverse the file system to access files or directories that are outside of the restricted directory.</html:p>
            <html:p>The '/dir/../filename' manipulation is useful for bypassing some path traversal protection schemes. Sometimes a program only checks for "../" at the beginning of the input, so a "/../" can bypass that check.</html:p>
         </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: The product stores a password in a configuration file that might be accessible to actors who do not know the password.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product stores a password in a configuration file that might be accessible to actors who do not know the password.
cwe.name: Password in Configuration File
cwe.extended_summary: This can result in compromise of the system for which the password is used. An attacker could gain access to this file and learn the stored password or worse yet, change the password to one of their choosing.

cwe.description: Obscuring a password with a trivial encoding does not protect the password.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: Obscuring a password with a trivial encoding does not protect the password.
cwe.name: Weak Encoding for Password
cwe.extended_summary: Password management issues occur when a password is stored in plaintext in an application's properties or configuration file. A programmer can attempt to remedy the password management problem by obscuring the password with an encoding function, such as base 64 encoding, but this effort does not adequately protect the password.

cwe.description: The product does not have a mechanism in place for managing password aging.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>As passwords age, the probability that they are compromised grows.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product does not have a mechanism in place for managing password aging.
cwe.name: Not Using Password Aging
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
	 <html:p>Password aging (or password rotation) is a policy that forces users to change their passwords after a defined time period passes, such as every 30 or 90 days. Without mechanisms such as aging, users might not change their passwords in a timely manner.</html:p>
	 <html:p>Note that while password aging was once considered an important security feature, it has since fallen out of favor by many, because it is not as effective against modern threats compared to other mechanisms such as slow hashes. In addition, forcing frequent changes can unintentionally encourage users to select less-secure passwords. However, password aging is still in use due to factors such as compliance requirements, e.g., Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard (PCI DSS).</html:p>
	 </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: The product supports password aging, but the expiration period is too long.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>As passwords age, the probability that they are compromised grows.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product supports password aging, but the expiration period is too long.
cwe.name: Password Aging with Long Expiration
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
	   <html:p>Password aging (or password rotation) is a policy that forces users to change their passwords after a defined time period passes, such as every 30 or 90 days. A long expiration provides more time for attackers to conduct password cracking before users are forced to change to a new password.</html:p>
	   <html:p>Note that while password aging was once considered an important security feature, it has since fallen out of favor by many, because it is not as effective against modern threats compared to other mechanisms such as slow hashes. In addition, forcing frequent changes can unintentionally encourage users to select less-secure passwords. However, password aging is still in use due to factors such as compliance requirements, e.g., Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard (PCI DSS).</html:p>
	 </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: A product incorrectly assigns a privilege to a particular actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>A user can access restricted functionality and/or sensitive information that may include administrative functionality and user accounts.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: A product incorrectly assigns a privilege to a particular actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.
cwe.name: Incorrect Privilege Assignment

cwe.description: A particular privilege, role, capability, or right can be used to perform unsafe actions that were not intended, even when it is assigned to the correct entity.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>A user can access restricted functionality and/or sensitive information that may include administrative functionality and user accounts.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: A particular privilege, role, capability, or right can be used to perform unsafe actions that were not intended, even when it is assigned to the correct entity.
cwe.name: Privilege Defined With Unsafe Actions

cwe.description: Two distinct privileges, roles, capabilities, or rights can be combined in a way that allows an entity to perform unsafe actions that would not be allowed without that combination.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>A user can be given or gain access rights of another user. This can give the user unauthorized access to sensitive information including the access information of another user.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: Two distinct privileges, roles, capabilities, or rights can be combined in a way that allows an entity to perform unsafe actions that would not be allowed without that combination.
cwe.name: Privilege Chaining

cwe.description: The product does not properly assign, modify, track, or check privileges for an actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product does not properly assign, modify, track, or check privileges for an actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.
cwe.name: Improper Privilege Management

cwe.description: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize multiple internal "../" sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize multiple internal "../" sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.
cwe.name: Path Traversal: 'dir/../../filename'
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <html:p>This allows attackers to traverse the file system to access files or directories that are outside of the restricted directory.</html:p>
            <html:p>The 'directory/../../filename' manipulation is useful for bypassing some path traversal protection schemes. Sometimes a program only removes one "../" sequence, so multiple "../" can bypass that check. Alternately, this manipulation could be used to bypass a check for "../" at the beginning of the pathname, moving up more than one directory level.</html:p>
         </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: The product does not properly manage privileges while it is switching between different contexts that have different privileges or spheres of control.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>A user can assume the identity of another user with separate privileges in another context. This will give the user unauthorized access that may allow them to acquire the access information of other users.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product does not properly manage privileges while it is switching between different contexts that have different privileges or spheres of control.
cwe.name: Privilege Context Switching Error

cwe.description: The product does not drop privileges before passing control of a resource to an actor that does not have those privileges.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>If privileges are not dropped, neither are access rights of the user. Often these rights can be prevented from being dropped.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Non-Repudiation</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Hide Activities</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>If privileges are not dropped, in some cases the system may record actions as the user which is being impersonated rather than the impersonator.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product does not drop privileges before passing control of a resource to an actor that does not have those privileges.
cwe.name: Privilege Dropping / Lowering Errors
cwe.extended_summary: In some contexts, a system executing with elevated permissions will hand off a process/file/etc. to another process or user. If the privileges of an entity are not reduced, then elevated privileges are spread throughout a system and possibly to an attacker.

cwe.description: The elevated privilege level required to perform operations such as chroot() should be dropped immediately after the operation is performed.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>An attacker may be able to access resources with the elevated privilege that could not be accessed with the attacker's original privileges. This is particularly likely in conjunction with another flaw, such as a buffer overflow.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The elevated privilege level required to perform operations such as chroot() should be dropped immediately after the operation is performed.
cwe.name: Least Privilege Violation

cwe.description: The product attempts to drop privileges but does not check or incorrectly checks to see if the drop succeeded.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>If privileges are not dropped, neither are access rights of the user. Often these rights can be prevented from being dropped.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Non-Repudiation</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Hide Activities</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>If privileges are not dropped, in some cases the system may record actions as the user which is being impersonated rather than the impersonator.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product attempts to drop privileges but does not check or incorrectly checks to see if the drop succeeded.
cwe.name: Improper Check for Dropped Privileges
cwe.extended_summary: If the drop fails, the product will continue to run with the raised privileges, which might provide additional access to unprivileged users.

cwe.description: The product does not handle or incorrectly handles when it has insufficient privileges to perform an operation, leading to resultant weaknesses.

               <ns0:Impact>Other</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Alter Execution Logic</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product does not handle or incorrectly handles when it has insufficient privileges to perform an operation, leading to resultant weaknesses.
cwe.name: Improper Handling of Insufficient Privileges

cwe.description: During installation, installed file permissions are set to allow anyone to modify those files.

               <ns0:Impact>Modify Application Data</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>

         '
cwe.summary: A product defines a set of insecure permissions that are inherited by objects that are created by the program.
cwe.name: Insecure Inherited Permissions

cwe.description: A product inherits a set of insecure permissions for an object, e.g. when copying from an archive file, without user awareness or involvement.

b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>

            </ns0:Consequence>

         '
cwe.summary: A product inherits a set of insecure permissions for an object, e.g. when copying from an archive file, without user awareness or involvement.
cwe.name: Insecure Preserved Inherited Permissions

cwe.description: While it is executing, the product sets the permissions of an object in a way that violates the intended permissions that have been specified by the user.

            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Application Data</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: While it is executing, the product sets the permissions of an object in a way that violates the intended permissions that have been specified by the user.
cwe.name: Incorrect Execution-Assigned Permissions

cwe.description: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize "..\" sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize "..\" sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.
cwe.name: Path Traversal: '..\filedir'
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <html:p>This allows attackers to traverse the file system to access files or directories that are outside of the restricted directory.</html:p>
            <html:p>The '..\' manipulation is the canonical manipulation for operating systems that use "\" as directory separators, such as Windows. However, it is also useful for bypassing path traversal protection schemes that only assume that the "/" separator is valid.</html:p>
         </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: The product does not handle or incorrectly handles when it has insufficient privileges to access resources or functionality as specified by their permissions. This may cause it to follow unexpected code paths that may leave the product in an invalid state.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Other</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Alter Execution Logic</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product does not handle or incorrectly handles when it has insufficient privileges to access resources or functionality as specified by their permissions. This may cause it to follow unexpected code paths that may leave the product in an invalid state.
cwe.name: Improper Handling of Insufficient Permissions or Privileges

cwe.description: The product does not preserve permissions or incorrectly preserves permissions when copying, restoring, or sharing objects, which can cause them to have less restrictive permissions than intended.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Application Data</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product does not preserve permissions or incorrectly preserves permissions when copying, restoring, or sharing objects, which can cause them to have less restrictive permissions than intended.
cwe.name: Improper Preservation of Permissions

cwe.description: The product assigns the wrong ownership, or does not properly verify the ownership, of an object or resource.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product assigns the wrong ownership, or does not properly verify the ownership, of an object or resource.
cwe.name: Improper Ownership Management

cwe.description: The product does not properly verify that a critical resource is owned by the proper entity.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>An attacker could gain unauthorized access to system resources.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product does not properly verify that a critical resource is owned by the proper entity.
cwe.name: Unverified Ownership

cwe.description: The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Varies by Context</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.
cwe.name: Improper Access Control
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <html:p>Access control involves the use of several protection mechanisms such as:</html:p>
            <html:ul>
               <html:li>Authentication (proving the identity of an actor)</html:li>
               <html:li>Authorization (ensuring that a given actor can access a resource), and</html:li>
               <html:li>Accountability (tracking of activities that were performed)</html:li>
            </html:ul>
            <html:p>When any mechanism is not applied or otherwise fails, attackers can compromise the security of the product by gaining privileges, reading sensitive information, executing commands, evading detection, etc.</html:p>
            <html:p>There are two distinct behaviors that can introduce access control weaknesses:</html:p>
               <html:ul>
                  <html:li>Specification: incorrect privileges, permissions, ownership, etc. are explicitly specified for either the user or the resource (for example, setting a password file to be world-writable, or giving administrator capabilities to a guest user). This action could be performed by the program or the administrator.</html:li>
                  <html:li>Enforcement: the mechanism contains errors that prevent it from properly enforcing the specified access control requirements (e.g., allowing the user to specify their own privileges, or allowing a syntactically-incorrect ACL to produce insecure settings). This problem occurs within the program itself, in that it does not actually enforce the intended security policy that the administrator specifies.</html:li>
               </html:ul>
         </ns0:Extended_Description>
		 '

cwe.description: The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>An attacker could read sensitive data, either by reading the data directly from a data store that is not properly restricted, or by accessing insufficiently-protected, privileged functionality to read the data.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>An attacker could modify sensitive data, either by writing the data directly to a data store that is not properly restricted, or by accessing insufficiently-protected, privileged functionality to write the data.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>An attacker could gain privileges by modifying or reading critical data directly, or by accessing insufficiently-protected, privileged functionality.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.
cwe.name: Improper Authorization
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <html:p>Assuming a user with a given identity, authorization is the process of determining whether that user can access a given resource, based on the user's privileges and any permissions or other access-control specifications that apply to the resource.</html:p>
            <html:p>When access control checks are not applied consistently - or not at all - users are able to access data or perform actions that they should not be allowed to perform. This can lead to a wide range of problems, including information exposures, denial of service, and arbitrary code execution.</html:p>
         </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: The product does not properly manage a user within its environment.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Varies by Context</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
	 '
cwe.summary: The product does not properly manage a user within its environment.
cwe.name: Incorrect User Management
cwe.extended_summary: Users can be assigned to the wrong group (class) of permissions resulting in unintended access rights to sensitive objects.

cwe.description: When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Execute Unauthorized Code or Commands</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>This weakness can lead to the exposure of resources or functionality to unintended actors, possibly providing attackers with sensitive information or even execute arbitrary code.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.
cwe.name: Improper Authentication

cwe.description: A product requires authentication, but the product has an alternate path or channel that does not require authentication.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Bypass Protection Mechanism</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: A product requires authentication, but the product has an alternate path or channel that does not require authentication.
cwe.name: Authentication Bypass Using an Alternate Path or Channel

cwe.description: The product performs authentication based on the name of a resource being accessed, or the name of the actor performing the access, but it does not properly check all possible names for that resource or actor.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Bypass Protection Mechanism</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product performs authentication based on the name of a resource being accessed, or the name of the actor performing the access, but it does not properly check all possible names for that resource or actor.
cwe.name: Authentication Bypass by Alternate Name

cwe.description: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize '\..\filename' (leading backslash dot dot) sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize '\..\filename' (leading backslash dot dot) sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.
cwe.name: Path Traversal: '\..\filename'
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <html:p>This allows attackers to traverse the file system to access files or directories that are outside of the restricted directory.</html:p>
            <html:p>This is similar to CWE-25, except using "\" instead of "/". Sometimes a program checks for "..\" at the beginning of the input, so a "\..\" can bypass that check. It is also useful for bypassing path traversal protection schemes that only assume that the "/" separator is valid.</html:p>
         </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: This attack-focused weakness is caused by incorrectly implemented authentication schemes that are subject to spoofing attacks.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Bypass Protection Mechanism</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>This weakness can allow an attacker to access resources which are not otherwise accessible without proper authentication.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: This attack-focused weakness is caused by incorrectly implemented authentication schemes that are subject to spoofing attacks.
cwe.name: Authentication Bypass by Spoofing

cwe.description: The product uses an IP address for authentication.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Non-Repudiation</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Hide Activities</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>Malicious users can fake authentication information, impersonating any IP address.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product uses an IP address for authentication.
cwe.name: Reliance on IP Address for Authentication
cwe.extended_summary: IP addresses can be easily spoofed. Attackers can forge the source IP address of the packets they send, but response packets will return to the forged IP address. To see the response packets, the attacker has to sniff the traffic between the victim machine and the forged IP address. In order to accomplish the required sniffing, attackers typically attempt to locate themselves on the same subnet as the victim machine. Attackers may be able to circumvent this requirement by using source routing, but source routing is disabled across much of the Internet today. In summary, IP address verification can be a useful part of an authentication scheme, but it should not be the single factor required for authentication.

cwe.description: This entry has been deprecated because it was a duplicate of CWE-350. All content has been transferred to CWE-350.
cwe.summary: This entry has been deprecated because it was a duplicate of CWE-350. All content has been transferred to CWE-350.
cwe.name: DEPRECATED: Trusting Self-reported DNS Name

cwe.description: The referer field in HTTP requests can be easily modified and, as such, is not a valid means of message integrity checking.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>Actions, which may not be authorized otherwise, can be carried out as if they were validated by the server referred to.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The referer field in HTTP requests can be easily modified and, as such, is not a valid means of message integrity checking.
cwe.name: Using Referer Field for Authentication

cwe.description: A capture-replay flaw exists when the design of the product makes it possible for a malicious user to sniff network traffic and bypass authentication by replaying it to the server in question to the same effect as the original message (or with minor changes).
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>Messages sent with a capture-relay attack allow access to resources which are not otherwise accessible without proper authentication.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: A capture-replay flaw exists when the design of the product makes it possible for a malicious user to sniff network traffic and bypass authentication by replaying it to the server in question to the same effect as the original message (or with minor changes).
cwe.name: Authentication Bypass by Capture-replay
cwe.extended_summary: Capture-replay attacks are common and can be difficult to defeat without cryptography. They are a subset of network injection attacks that rely on observing previously-sent valid commands, then changing them slightly if necessary and resending the same commands to the server.

cwe.description: The product does not validate, or incorrectly validates, a certificate.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Authentication</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Bypass Protection Mechanism</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product does not validate, or incorrectly validates, a certificate.
cwe.name: Improper Certificate Validation
cwe.extended_summary: When a certificate is invalid or malicious, it might allow an attacker to spoof a trusted entity by interfering in the communication path between the host and client. The product might connect to a malicious host while believing it is a trusted host, or the product might be deceived into accepting spoofed data that appears to originate from a trusted host.

cwe.description: The product does not follow, or incorrectly follows, the chain of trust for a certificate back to a trusted root certificate, resulting in incorrect trust of any resource that is associated with that certificate.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Non-Repudiation</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Hide Activities</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>Exploitation of this flaw can lead to the trust of data that may have originated with a spoofed source.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Execute Unauthorized Code or Commands</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>Data, requests, or actions taken by the attacking entity can be carried out as a spoofed benign entity.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product does not follow, or incorrectly follows, the chain of trust for a certificate back to a trusted root certificate, resulting in incorrect trust of any resource that is associated with that certificate.
cwe.name: Improper Following of a Certificate's Chain of Trust
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <html:p>If a system does not follow the chain of trust of a certificate to a root server, the certificate loses all usefulness as a metric of trust. Essentially, the trust gained from a certificate is derived from a chain of trust -- with a reputable trusted entity at the end of that list. The end user must trust that reputable source, and this reputable source must vouch for the resource in question through the medium of the certificate.</html:p>
            <html:p>In some cases, this trust traverses several entities who vouch for one another. The entity trusted by the end user is at one end of this trust chain, while the certificate-wielding resource is at the other end of the chain. If the user receives a certificate at the end of one of these trust chains and then proceeds to check only that the first link in the chain, no real trust has been derived, since the entire chain must be traversed back to a trusted source to verify the certificate.</html:p>
            <html:p>There are several ways in which the chain of trust might be broken, including but not limited to:</html:p>
            <html:ul>
              <html:li>Any certificate in the chain is self-signed, unless it the root.</html:li>
              <html:li>Not every intermediate certificate is checked, starting from the original certificate all the way up to the root certificate.</html:li>
              <html:li>An intermediate, CA-signed certificate does not have the expected Basic Constraints or other important extensions.</html:li>
              <html:li>The root certificate has been compromised or authorized to the wrong party.</html:li>
            </html:ul>
         </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: The product communicates with a host that provides a certificate, but the product does not properly ensure that the certificate is actually associated with that host.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>The data read from the system vouched for by the certificate may not be from the expected system.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Authentication</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Other</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>Trust afforded to the system in question - based on the malicious certificate - may allow for spoofing or redirection attacks.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product communicates with a host that provides a certificate, but the product does not properly ensure that the certificate is actually associated with that host.
cwe.name: Improper Validation of Certificate with Host Mismatch
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <html:p>Even if a certificate is well-formed, signed, and follows the chain of trust, it may simply be a valid certificate for a different site than the site that the product is interacting with. If the certificate's host-specific data is not properly checked - such as the Common Name (CN) in the Subject or the Subject Alternative Name (SAN) extension of an X.509 certificate - it may be possible for a redirection or spoofing attack to allow a malicious host with a valid certificate to provide data, impersonating a trusted host. In order to ensure data integrity, the certificate must be valid and it must pertain to the site that is being accessed.</html:p>
            <html:p>Even if the product attempts to check the hostname, it is still possible to incorrectly check the hostname. For example, attackers could create a certificate with a name that begins with a trusted name followed by a NUL byte, which could cause some string-based comparisons to only examine the portion that contains the trusted name.</html:p>
            <html:p>This weakness can occur even when the product uses Certificate Pinning, if the product does not verify the hostname at the time a certificate is pinned.</html:p>
         </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: A certificate expiration is not validated or is incorrectly validated, so trust may be assigned to certificates that have been abandoned due to age.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Other</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>The data read from the system vouched for by the expired certificate may be flawed due to malicious spoofing.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Authentication</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Other</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>Trust afforded to the system in question - based on the expired certificate - may allow for spoofing attacks.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: A certificate expiration is not validated or is incorrectly validated, so trust may be assigned to certificates that have been abandoned due to age.
cwe.name: Improper Validation of Certificate Expiration
cwe.extended_summary: When the expiration of a certificate is not taken into account, no trust has necessarily been conveyed through it. Therefore, the validity of the certificate cannot be verified and all benefit of the certificate is lost.

cwe.description: The product does not check or incorrectly checks the revocation status of a certificate, which may cause it to use a certificate that has been compromised.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>Trust may be assigned to an entity who is not who it claims to be.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Other</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>Data from an untrusted (and possibly malicious) source may be integrated.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>Data may be disclosed to an entity impersonating a trusted entity, resulting in information disclosure.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product does not check or incorrectly checks the revocation status of a certificate, which may cause it to use a certificate that has been compromised.
cwe.name: Improper Check for Certificate Revocation
cwe.extended_summary: An improper check for certificate revocation is a far more serious flaw than related certificate failures. This is because the use of any revoked certificate is almost certainly malicious. The most common reason for certificate revocation is compromise of the system in question, with the result that no legitimate servers will be using a revoked certificate, unless they are sorely out of sync.

cwe.description: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize '\dir\..\filename' (leading backslash dot dot) sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize '\dir\..\filename' (leading backslash dot dot) sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.
cwe.name: Path Traversal: '\dir\..\filename'
cwe.extended_summary:
