cwe.summary: Accessible test applications can pose a variety of security risks. Since developers or administrators rarely consider that someone besides themselves would even know about the existence of these applications, it is common for them to contain sensitive information or functions.
cwe.name: Inclusion of Sensitive Information in Test Code

cwe.description: Information written to log files can be of a sensitive nature and give valuable guidance to an attacker or expose sensitive user information.

b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>Logging sensitive user data often provides attackers with an additional, less-protected path to acquiring the information.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: Information written to log files can be of a sensitive nature and give valuable guidance to an attacker or expose sensitive user information.
cwe.name: Insertion of Sensitive Information into Log File
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <html:p>While logging all information may be helpful during development stages, it is important that logging levels be set appropriately before a product ships so that sensitive user data and system information are not accidentally exposed to potential attackers.</html:p>
            <html:p>Different log files may be produced and stored for:</html:p>
            <html:ul>
               <html:li>Server log files (e.g. server.log).  This can give information on whatever application left the file. Usually this can give full path names and system information, and sometimes usernames and passwords.</html:li>
               <html:li>log files that are used for debugging</html:li>
            </html:ul>
         </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

This may disclose the web root's absolute path as well as give the attacker the location of application files or configuration information. It may even disclose the portion of code that failed. In many cases, an attacker can use the data to launch further attacks against the system.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: A servlet error message indicates that there exists an unhandled exception in your web application code and may provide useful information to an attacker.
cwe.name: Servlet Runtime Error Message Containing Sensitive Information

cwe.description: The web application uses persistent cookies, but the cookies contain sensitive information.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The web application uses persistent cookies, but the cookies contain sensitive information.
cwe.name: Use of Persistent Cookies Containing Sensitive Information
cwe.extended_summary: Cookies are small bits of data that are sent by the web application but stored locally in the browser. This lets the application use the cookie to pass information between pages and store variable information. The web application controls what information is stored in a cookie and how it is used. Typical types of information stored in cookies are session identifiers, personalization and customization information, and in rare cases even usernames to enable automated logins. There are two different types of cookies: session cookies and persistent cookies. Session cookies just live in the browser's memory and are not stored anywhere, but persistent cookies are stored on the browser's hard drive.   This can cause security and privacy issues depending on the information stored in the cookie and how it is accessed.

cwe.description: The product accepts path input in the form of trailing backslash ('filedir\') without appropriate validation, which can lead to ambiguous path resolution and allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product accepts path input in the form of trailing backslash ('filedir\') without appropriate validation, which can lead to ambiguous path resolution and allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.
cwe.name: Path Equivalence: 'filedir\' (Trailing Backslash)

cwe.description: Source code on a web server or repository often contains sensitive information and should generally not be accessible to users.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: Source code on a web server or repository often contains sensitive information and should generally not be accessible to users.
cwe.name: Inclusion of Sensitive Information in Source Code
cwe.extended_summary: There are situations where it is critical to remove source code from an area or server. For example, obtaining Perl source code on a system allows an attacker to understand the logic of the script and extract extremely useful information such as code bugs or logins and passwords.

cwe.description: If an include file source is accessible, the file can contain usernames and passwords, as well as sensitive information pertaining to the application and system.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: If an include file source is accessible, the file can contain usernames and passwords, as well as sensitive information pertaining to the application and system.
cwe.name: Inclusion of Sensitive Information in an Include File

cwe.description: This entry has been deprecated because its abstraction was too low-level.  See CWE-532.
cwe.summary: This entry has been deprecated because its abstraction was too low-level.  See CWE-532.
cwe.name: DEPRECATED: Information Exposure Through Cleanup Log Files

cwe.description: The product uses the singleton pattern when creating a resource within a multithreaded environment.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Other</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Application Data</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product uses the singleton pattern when creating a resource within a multithreaded environment.
cwe.name: Use of Singleton Pattern Without Synchronization in a Multithreaded Context
cwe.extended_summary: The use of a singleton pattern may not be thread-safe.

cwe.description: The product does not use a standardized method for handling errors throughout the code, which might introduce inconsistent error handling and resultant weaknesses.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Quality Degradation</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Unexpected State</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Varies by Context</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product does not use a standardized method for handling errors throughout the code, which might introduce inconsistent error handling and resultant weaknesses.
cwe.name: Missing Standardized Error Handling Mechanism
cwe.extended_summary: If the product handles error messages individually, on a one-by-one basis, this is likely to result in inconsistent error handling. The causes of errors may be lost. Also, detailed information about the causes of an error may be unintentionally returned to the user.

cwe.description: This weakness has been deprecated because it partially overlaps CWE-470, it describes legitimate programmer behavior, and other portions will need to be integrated into other entries.
cwe.summary: This weakness has been deprecated because it partially overlaps CWE-470, it describes legitimate programmer behavior, and other portions will need to be integrated into other entries.
cwe.name: DEPRECATED: Use of Dynamic Class Loading

cwe.description: The code contains comments that suggest the presence of bugs, incomplete functionality, or weaknesses.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Quality Degradation</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>Suspicious comments could be an indication that there are problems in the source code that may need to be fixed and is an indication of poor quality. This could lead to further bugs and the introduction of weaknesses.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The code contains comments that suggest the presence of bugs, incomplete functionality, or weaknesses.
cwe.name: Suspicious Comment
cwe.extended_summary: Many suspicious comments, such as BUG, HACK, FIXME, LATER, LATER2, TODO, in the code indicate missing security functionality and checking. Others indicate code problems that programmers should fix, such as hard-coded variables, error handling, not using stored procedures, and performance issues.

cwe.description: The product uses hard-coded constants instead of symbolic names for security-critical values, which increases the likelihood of mistakes during code maintenance or security policy change.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Varies by Context</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Quality Degradation</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>The existence of hardcoded constants could cause unexpected behavior and the introduction of weaknesses during code maintenance or when making changes to the code if all occurrences are not modified. The use of hardcoded constants is an indication of poor quality.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product uses hard-coded constants instead of symbolic names for security-critical values, which increases the likelihood of mistakes during code maintenance or security policy change.
cwe.name: Use of Hard-coded, Security-relevant Constants
cwe.extended_summary: If the developer does not find all occurrences of the hard-coded constants, an incorrect policy decision may be made if one of the constants is not changed. Making changes to these values will require code changes that may be difficult or impossible once the system is released to the field. In addition, these hard-coded values may become available to attackers if the code is ever disclosed.

cwe.description: A directory listing is inappropriately exposed, yielding potentially sensitive information to attackers.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>Exposing the contents of a directory can lead to an attacker gaining access to source code or providing useful information for the attacker to devise exploits, such as creation times of files or any information that may be encoded in file names. The directory listing may also compromise private or confidential data.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: A directory listing is inappropriately exposed, yielding potentially sensitive information to attackers.
cwe.name: Exposure of Information Through Directory Listing
cwe.extended_summary: A directory listing provides an attacker with the complete index of all the resources located inside of the directory. The specific risks and consequences vary depending on which files are listed and accessible.

cwe.description: The product does not mask passwords during entry, increasing the potential for attackers to observe and capture passwords.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Bypass Protection Mechanism</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product does not mask passwords during entry, increasing the potential for attackers to observe and capture passwords.
cwe.name: Missing Password Field Masking

cwe.description: The product accepts path input in the form of single dot directory exploit ('/./') without appropriate validation, which can lead to ambiguous path resolution and allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product accepts path input in the form of single dot directory exploit ('/./') without appropriate validation, which can lead to ambiguous path resolution and allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.
cwe.name: Path Equivalence: '/./' (Single Dot Directory)

cwe.description: Certain conditions, such as network failure, will cause a server error message to be displayed.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: Certain conditions, such as network failure, will cause a server error message to be displayed.
cwe.name: Server-generated Error Message Containing Sensitive Information
cwe.extended_summary: While error messages in and of themselves are not dangerous, per se, it is what an attacker can glean from them that might cause eventual problems.

cwe.description: If a web server does not fully parse requested URLs before it examines them for authorization, it may be possible for an attacker to bypass authorization protection.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Bypass Protection Mechanism</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: If a web server does not fully parse requested URLs before it examines them for authorization, it may be possible for an attacker to bypass authorization protection.
cwe.name: Incorrect Behavior Order: Authorization Before Parsing and Canonicalization
cwe.extended_summary: For instance, the character strings /./ and / both mean current directory. If /SomeDirectory is a protected directory and an attacker requests /./SomeDirectory, the attacker may be able to gain access to the resource if /./ is not converted to / before the authorization check is performed.

cwe.description: The product makes files or directories accessible to unauthorized actors, even though they should not be.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product makes files or directories accessible to unauthorized actors, even though they should not be.
cwe.name: Files or Directories Accessible to External Parties
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
	   <html:p>Web servers, FTP servers, and similar servers may store a set of files underneath a "root" directory that is accessible to the server's users.  Applications may store sensitive files underneath this root without also using access control to limit which users may request those files, if any.  Alternately, an application might package multiple files or directories into an archive file (e.g., ZIP or tar), but the application might not exclude sensitive files that are underneath those directories.</html:p>
	   <html:p>In cloud technologies and containers, this weakness might present itself in the form of misconfigured storage accounts that can be read or written by a public or anonymous user.</html:p>
	 </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: A possible shell file exists in /cgi-bin/ or other accessible directories. This is extremely dangerous and can be used by an attacker to execute commands on the web server.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Execute Unauthorized Code or Commands</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: A possible shell file exists in /cgi-bin/ or other accessible directories. This is extremely dangerous and can be used by an attacker to execute commands on the web server.
cwe.name: Command Shell in Externally Accessible Directory

cwe.description: The ASP.NET application does not use an input validation framework.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Unexpected State</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>Unchecked input leads to cross-site scripting, process control, and SQL injection vulnerabilities, among others.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The ASP.NET application does not use an input validation framework.
cwe.name: ASP.NET Misconfiguration: Not Using Input Validation Framework

cwe.description: The J2EE application stores a plaintext password in a configuration file.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Bypass Protection Mechanism</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The J2EE application stores a plaintext password in a configuration file.
cwe.name: J2EE Misconfiguration: Plaintext Password in Configuration File
cwe.extended_summary: Storing a plaintext password in a configuration file allows anyone who can read the file to access the password-protected resource, making it an easy target for attackers.

cwe.description: Configuring an ASP.NET application to run with impersonated credentials may give the application unnecessary privileges.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: Configuring an ASP.NET application to run with impersonated credentials may give the application unnecessary privileges.
cwe.name: ASP.NET Misconfiguration: Use of Identity Impersonation
cwe.extended_summary: The use of impersonated credentials allows an ASP.NET application to run with either the privileges of the client on whose behalf it is executing or with arbitrary privileges granted in its configuration.

cwe.description: The product uses the getlogin() function in a multithreaded context, potentially causing it to return incorrect values.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Bypass Protection Mechanism</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Other</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product uses the getlogin() function in a multithreaded context, potentially causing it to return incorrect values.
cwe.name: Use of getlogin() in Multithreaded Application
cwe.extended_summary: The getlogin() function returns a pointer to a string that contains the name of the user associated with the calling process. The function is not reentrant, meaning that if it is called from another process, the contents are not locked out and the value of the string can be changed by another process. This makes it very risky to use because the username can be changed by other processes, so the results of the function cannot be trusted.

cwe.description: The product accepts path input in the form of asterisk wildcard ('filedir*') without appropriate validation, which can lead to ambiguous path resolution and allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product accepts path input in the form of asterisk wildcard ('filedir*') without appropriate validation, which can lead to ambiguous path resolution and allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.
cwe.name: Path Equivalence: 'filedir*' (Wildcard)

cwe.description: The product calls umask() with an incorrect argument that is specified as if it is an argument to chmod().
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Bypass Protection Mechanism</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product calls umask() with an incorrect argument that is specified as if it is an argument to chmod().
cwe.name: Use of umask() with chmod-style Argument

cwe.description: The product contains dead code, which can never be executed.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Quality Degradation</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>Dead code that results from code that can never be executed is an indication of problems with the source code that needs to be fixed and is an indication of poor quality.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Reduce Maintainability</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product contains dead code, which can never be executed.
cwe.name: Dead Code
cwe.extended_summary: Dead code is code that can never be executed in a running program. The surrounding code makes it impossible for a section of code to ever be executed.

cwe.description: A function returns the address of a stack variable, which will cause unintended program behavior, typically in the form of a crash.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Memory</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Memory</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Execute Unauthorized Code or Commands</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>DoS: Crash, Exit, or Restart</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>If the returned stack buffer address is dereferenced after the return, then an attacker may be able to modify or read memory, depending on how the address is used.  If the address is used for reading, then the address itself may be exposed, or the contents that the address points to.  If the address is used for writing, this can lead to a crash and possibly code execution.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: A function returns the address of a stack variable, which will cause unintended program behavior, typically in the form of a crash.
cwe.name: Return of Stack Variable Address
cwe.extended_summary: Because local variables are allocated on the stack, when a program returns a pointer to a local variable, it is returning a stack address. A subsequent function call is likely to re-use this same stack address, thereby overwriting the value of the pointer, which no longer corresponds to the same variable since a function's stack frame is invalidated when it returns. At best this will cause the value of the pointer to change unexpectedly. In many cases it causes the program to crash the next time the pointer is dereferenced.

cwe.description: The variable's value is assigned but never used, making it a dead store.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Quality Degradation</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Varies by Context</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>This weakness could be an indication of a bug in the program or a deprecated variable that was not removed and is an indication of poor quality. This could lead to further bugs and the introduction of weaknesses.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The variable's value is assigned but never used, making it a dead store.
cwe.name: Assignment to Variable without Use
cwe.extended_summary: After the assignment, the variable is either assigned another value or goes out of scope. It is likely that the variable is simply vestigial, but it is also possible that the unused variable points out a bug.

cwe.description: Using Hibernate to execute a dynamic SQL statement built with user-controlled input can allow an attacker to modify the statement's meaning or to execute arbitrary SQL commands.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Application Data</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: Using Hibernate to execute a dynamic SQL statement built with user-controlled input can allow an attacker to modify the statement's meaning or to execute arbitrary SQL commands.
cwe.name: SQL Injection: Hibernate

cwe.description: The product relies on the existence or values of cookies when performing security-critical operations, but it does not properly ensure that the setting is valid for the associated user.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>It is dangerous to use cookies to set a user's privileges. The cookie can be manipulated to escalate an attacker's privileges to an administrative level.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product relies on the existence or values of cookies when performing security-critical operations, but it does not properly ensure that the setting is valid for the associated user.
cwe.name: Reliance on Cookies without Validation and Integrity Checking
cwe.extended_summary: Attackers can easily modify cookies, within the browser or by implementing the client-side code outside of the browser. Reliance on cookies without detailed validation and integrity checking can allow attackers to bypass authentication, conduct injection attacks such as SQL injection and cross-site scripting, or otherwise modify inputs in unexpected ways.

cwe.description: The product uses a database table that includes records that should not be accessible to an actor, but it executes a SQL statement with a primary key that can be controlled by that actor.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Bypass Protection Mechanism</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product uses a database table that includes records that should not be accessible to an actor, but it executes a SQL statement with a primary key that can be controlled by that actor.
cwe.name: Authorization Bypass Through User-Controlled SQL Primary Key
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <html:p>When a user can set a primary key to any value, then the user can modify the key to point to unauthorized records.</html:p>
            <html:p>Database access control errors occur when:</html:p>
               <html:ul>
                  <html:li>Data enters a program from an untrusted source.</html:li>
                  <html:li>The data is used to specify the value of a primary key in a SQL query.</html:li>
                  <html:li>The untrusted source does not have the permissions to be able to access all rows in the associated table.</html:li>
               </html:ul>
         </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: The product does not properly synchronize shared data, such as static variables across threads, which can lead to undefined behavior and unpredictable data changes.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>DoS: Instability</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>DoS: Crash, Exit, or Restart</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>If the shared variable contains sensitive data, it may be manipulated or displayed in another user session. If this data is used to control the application, its value can be manipulated to cause the application to crash or perform poorly.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product does not properly synchronize shared data, such as static variables across threads, which can lead to undefined behavior and unpredictable data changes.
cwe.name: Unsynchronized Access to Shared Data in a Multithreaded Context
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <html:p>Within servlets, shared static variables are not protected from concurrent access, but servlets are multithreaded. This is a typical programming mistake in J2EE applications, since the multithreading is handled by the framework. When a shared variable can be influenced by an attacker, one thread could wind up modifying the variable to contain data that is not valid for a different thread that is also using the data within the variable.</html:p>
            <html:p>Note that this weakness is not unique to servlets.</html:p>
         </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: The product contains a finalize() method that does not call super.finalize().
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Quality Degradation</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product contains a finalize() method that does not call super.finalize().
cwe.name: finalize() Method Without super.finalize()
cwe.extended_summary: The Java Language Specification states that it is a good practice for a finalize() method to call super.finalize().

cwe.description: The product contains protection mechanisms to restrict access to 'realdir/filename', but it constructs pathnames using external input in the form of 'fakedir/../realdir/filename' that are not handled by those mechanisms. This allows attackers to perform unauthorized actions against the targeted file.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product contains protection mechanisms to restrict access to 'realdir/filename', but it constructs pathnames using external input in the form of 'fakedir/../realdir/filename' that are not handled by those mechanisms. This allows attackers to perform unauthorized actions against the targeted file.
cwe.name: Path Equivalence: 'fakedir/../realdir/filename'

cwe.description: The product contains an expression that will always evaluate to false.

               <ns0:Impact>Varies by Context</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product contains an expression that will always evaluate to false.
cwe.name: Expression is Always False

cwe.description: The product contains an expression that will always evaluate to true.

b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">

               <ns0:Impact>Quality Degradation</ns0:Impact>

cwe.name: Expression is Always True

cwe.description: The product calls a thread's run() method instead of calling start(), which causes the code to run in the thread of the caller instead of the callee.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Quality Degradation</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Varies by Context</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product calls a thread's run() method instead of calling start(), which causes the code to run in the thread of the caller instead of the callee.
cwe.name: Call to Thread run() instead of start()
cwe.extended_summary: In most cases a direct call to a Thread object's run() method is a bug. The programmer intended to begin a new thread of control, but accidentally called run() instead of start(), so the run() method will execute in the caller's thread of control.

cwe.description: The product does not follow or incorrectly follows the specifications as required by the implementation language, environment, framework, protocol, or platform.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Quality Degradation</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Varies by Context</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product does not follow or incorrectly follows the specifications as required by the implementation language, environment, framework, protocol, or platform.
cwe.name: Improper Following of Specification by Caller
cwe.extended_summary: When leveraging external functionality, such as an API, it is important that the caller does so in accordance with the requirements of the external functionality or else unintended behaviors may result, possibly leaving the system vulnerable to any number of exploits.

cwe.description: The product violates the Enterprise JavaBeans (EJB) specification by using thread synchronization primitives.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Quality Degradation</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product violates the Enterprise JavaBeans (EJB) specification by using thread synchronization primitives.
cwe.name: EJB Bad Practices: Use of Synchronization Primitives
cwe.extended_summary: The Enterprise JavaBeans specification requires that every bean provider follow a set of programming guidelines designed to ensure that the bean will be portable and behave consistently in any EJB container. In this case, the product violates the following EJB guideline: "An enterprise bean must not use thread synchronization primitives to synchronize execution of multiple instances." The specification justifies this requirement in the following way: "This rule is required to ensure consistent runtime semantics because while some EJB containers may use a single JVM to execute all enterprise bean's instances, others may distribute the instances across multiple JVMs."

cwe.description: The product violates the Enterprise JavaBeans (EJB) specification by using AWT/Swing.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Quality Degradation</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product violates the Enterprise JavaBeans (EJB) specification by using AWT/Swing.
cwe.name: EJB Bad Practices: Use of AWT Swing
cwe.extended_summary: The Enterprise JavaBeans specification requires that every bean provider follow a set of programming guidelines designed to ensure that the bean will be portable and behave consistently in any EJB container. In this case, the product violates the following EJB guideline: "An enterprise bean must not use the AWT functionality to attempt to output information to a display, or to input information from a keyboard." The specification justifies this requirement in the following way: "Most servers do not allow direct interaction between an application program and a keyboard/display attached to the server system."

cwe.description: The product violates the Enterprise JavaBeans (EJB) specification by using the java.io package.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Quality Degradation</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product violates the Enterprise JavaBeans (EJB) specification by using the java.io package.
cwe.name: EJB Bad Practices: Use of Java I/O
cwe.extended_summary: The Enterprise JavaBeans specification requires that every bean provider follow a set of programming guidelines designed to ensure that the bean will be portable and behave consistently in any EJB container. In this case, the product violates the following EJB guideline: "An enterprise bean must not use the java.io package to attempt to access files and directories in the file system." The specification justifies this requirement in the following way: "The file system APIs are not well-suited for business components to access data. Business components should use a resource manager API, such as JDBC, to store data."

cwe.description: The product violates the Enterprise JavaBeans (EJB) specification by using sockets.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Quality Degradation</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product violates the Enterprise JavaBeans (EJB) specification by using sockets.
cwe.name: EJB Bad Practices: Use of Sockets
cwe.extended_summary: The Enterprise JavaBeans specification requires that every bean provider follow a set of programming guidelines designed to ensure that the bean will be portable and behave consistently in any EJB container. In this case, the product violates the following EJB guideline: "An enterprise bean must not attempt to listen on a socket, accept connections on a socket, or use a socket for multicast." The specification justifies this requirement in the following way: "The EJB architecture allows an enterprise bean instance to be a network socket client, but it does not allow it to be a network server. Allowing the instance to become a network server would conflict with the basic function of the enterprise bean-- to serve the EJB clients."

cwe.description: The product violates the Enterprise JavaBeans (EJB) specification by using the class loader.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Execute Unauthorized Code or Commands</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Varies by Context</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product violates the Enterprise JavaBeans (EJB) specification by using the class loader.
cwe.name: EJB Bad Practices: Use of Class Loader
cwe.extended_summary: The Enterprise JavaBeans specification requires that every bean provider follow a set of programming guidelines designed to ensure that the bean will be portable and behave consistently in any EJB container. In this case, the product violates the following EJB guideline: "The enterprise bean must not attempt to create a class loader; obtain the current class loader; set the context class loader; set security manager; create a new security manager; stop the JVM; or change the input, output, and error streams." The specification justifies this requirement in the following way: "These functions are reserved for the EJB container. Allowing the enterprise bean to use these functions could compromise security and decrease the container's ability to properly manage the runtime environment."

cwe.description: The product stores a non-serializable object as an HttpSession attribute, which can hurt reliability.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Quality Degradation</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product stores a non-serializable object as an HttpSession attribute, which can hurt reliability.
cwe.name: J2EE Bad Practices: Non-serializable Object Stored in Session
cwe.extended_summary: A J2EE application can make use of multiple JVMs in order to improve application reliability and performance. In order to make the multiple JVMs appear as a single application to the end user, the J2EE container can replicate an HttpSession object across multiple JVMs so that if one JVM becomes unavailable another can step in and take its place without disrupting the flow of the application. This is only possible if all session data is serializable, allowing the session to be duplicated between the JVMs.

cwe.description: The product contains a protection mechanism that restricts access to a long filename on a Windows operating system, but it does not properly restrict access to the equivalent short "8.3" filename.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product contains a protection mechanism that restricts access to a long filename on a Windows operating system, but it does not properly restrict access to the equivalent short "8.3" filename.
cwe.name: Path Equivalence: Windows 8.3 Filename
cwe.extended_summary: On later Windows operating systems, a file can have a "long name" and a short name that is compatible with older Windows file systems, with up to 8 characters in the filename and 3 characters for the extension. These "8.3" filenames, therefore, act as an alternate name for files with long names, so they are useful pathname equivalence manipulations.

cwe.description: The product contains a clone() method that does not call super.clone() to obtain the new object.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Unexpected State</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Quality Degradation</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product contains a clone() method that does not call super.clone() to obtain the new object.
cwe.name: clone() Method Without super.clone()
cwe.extended_summary: All implementations of clone() should obtain the new object by calling super.clone(). If a class does not follow this convention, a subclass's clone() method will return an object of the wrong type.

cwe.description: The product does not maintain equal hashcodes for equal objects.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Other</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>If this invariant is not upheld, it is likely to cause trouble if objects of this class are stored in a collection. If the objects of the class in question are used as a key in a Hashtable or if they are inserted into a Map or Set, it is critical that equal objects have equal hashcodes.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product does not maintain equal hashcodes for equal objects.
cwe.name: Object Model Violation: Just One of Equals and Hashcode Defined
cwe.extended_summary: Java objects are expected to obey a number of invariants related to equality. One of these invariants is that equal objects must have equal hashcodes. In other words, if a.equals(b) == true then a.hashCode() == b.hashCode().

cwe.description: The product declares an array public, final, and static, which is not sufficient to prevent the array's contents from being modified.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Application Data</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product declares an array public, final, and static, which is not sufficient to prevent the array's contents from being modified.
cwe.name: Array Declared Public, Final, and Static
cwe.extended_summary: Because arrays are mutable objects, the final constraint requires that the array object itself be assigned only once, but makes no guarantees about the values of the array elements. Since the array is public, a malicious program can change the values stored in the array. As such, in most cases an array declared public, final and static is a bug.

cwe.description: The product violates secure coding principles for mobile code by declaring a finalize() method public.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Alter Execution Logic</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Execute Unauthorized Code or Commands</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Application Data</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product violates secure coding principles for mobile code by declaring a finalize() method public.
cwe.name: finalize() Method Declared Public
cwe.extended_summary: A product should never call finalize explicitly, except to call super.finalize() inside an implementation of finalize(). In mobile code situations, the otherwise error prone practice of manual garbage collection can become a security threat if an attacker can maliciously invoke a finalize() method because it is declared with public access.

cwe.description: The code has a return statement inside a finally block, which will cause any thrown exception in the try block to be discarded.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Alter Execution Logic</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The code has a return statement inside a finally block, which will cause any thrown exception in the try block to be discarded.
cwe.name: Return Inside Finally Block

cwe.description: The product contains an empty synchronized block.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Other</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>An empty synchronized block will wait until nobody else is using the synchronizer being specified. While this may be part of the desired behavior, because you haven't protected the subsequent code by placing it inside the synchronized block, nothing is stopping somebody else from modifying whatever it was you were waiting for while you run the subsequent code.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product contains an empty synchronized block.
cwe.name: Empty Synchronized Block
cwe.extended_summary: An empty synchronized block does not actually accomplish any synchronization and may indicate a troubled section of code. An empty synchronized block can occur because code no longer needed within the synchronized block is commented out without removing the synchronized block.

cwe.description: The product makes an explicit call to the finalize() method from outside the finalizer.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Unexpected State</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Quality Degradation</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product makes an explicit call to the finalize() method from outside the finalizer.
cwe.name: Explicit Call to Finalize()
cwe.extended_summary: While the Java Language Specification allows an object's finalize() method to be called from outside the finalizer, doing so is usually a bad idea. For example, calling finalize() explicitly means that finalize() will be called more than once: the first time will be the explicit call and the last time will be the call that is made after the object is garbage collected.

cwe.description: The product sets a pointer to a specific address other than NULL or 0.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Execute Unauthorized Code or Commands</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>If one executes code at a known location, an attacker might be able to inject code there beforehand.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>DoS: Crash, Exit, or Restart</ns0:Impact>
	       <ns0:Impact>Reduce Maintainability</ns0:Impact>
	       <ns0:Impact>Reduce Reliability</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>If the code is ported to another platform or environment, the pointer is likely to be invalid and cause a crash.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Memory</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Memory</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>The data at a known pointer location can be easily read or influenced by an attacker.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product sets a pointer to a specific address other than NULL or 0.
cwe.name: Assignment of a Fixed Address to a Pointer
cwe.extended_summary: Using a fixed address is not portable, because that address will probably not be valid in all environments or platforms.

cwe.description: Casting a non-structure type to a structure type and accessing a field can lead to memory access errors or data corruption.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Memory</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>Adjacent variables in memory may be corrupted by assignments performed on fields after the cast.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>DoS: Crash, Exit, or Restart</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>Execution may end due to a memory access error.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: Casting a non-structure type to a structure type and accessing a field can lead to memory access errors or data corruption.
cwe.name: Attempt to Access Child of a Non-structure Pointer

cwe.description: The product uses an API function that does not exist on all versions of the target platform. This could cause portability problems or inconsistencies that allow denial of service or other consequences.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Quality Degradation</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product uses an API function that does not exist on all versions of the target platform. This could cause portability problems or inconsistencies that allow denial of service or other consequences.
cwe.name: Call to Non-ubiquitous API
cwe.extended_summary: Some functions that offer security features supported by the OS are not available on all versions of the OS in common use. Likewise, functions are often deprecated or made obsolete for security reasons and should not be used.

cwe.description: The product attempts to access a file based on the filename, but it does not properly prevent that filename from identifying a link or shortcut that resolves to an unintended resource.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Bypass Protection Mechanism</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>An attacker may be able to traverse the file system to unintended locations and read or overwrite the contents of unexpected files. If the files are used for a security mechanism then an attacker may be able to bypass the mechanism.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Execute Unauthorized Code or Commands</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>Windows simple shortcuts, sometimes referred to as soft links, can be exploited remotely since a ".LNK" file can be uploaded like a normal file. This can enable remote execution.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product attempts to access a file based on the filename, but it does not properly prevent that filename from identifying a link or shortcut that resolves to an unintended resource.
cwe.name: Improper Link Resolution Before File Access ('Link Following')

cwe.description: The product calls free() on a pointer to memory that was not allocated using associated heap allocation functions such as malloc(), calloc(), or realloc().
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Execute Unauthorized Code or Commands</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Memory</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>There is the potential for arbitrary code execution with privileges of the vulnerable program via a "write, what where" primitive. If pointers to memory which hold user information are freed, a malicious user will be able to write 4 bytes anywhere in memory.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product calls free() on a pointer to memory that was not allocated using associated heap allocation functions such as malloc(), calloc(), or realloc().
cwe.name: Free of Memory not on the Heap
cwe.extended_summary: When free() is called on an invalid pointer, the program's memory management data structures may become corrupted. This corruption can cause the program to crash or, in some circumstances, an attacker may be able to cause free() to operate on controllable memory locations to modify critical program variables or execute code.

cwe.description: The product stores sensitive data in memory that is not locked, or that has been incorrectly locked, which might cause the memory to be written to swap files on disk by the virtual memory manager. This can make the data more accessible to external actors.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Memory</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>Sensitive data that is written to a swap file may be exposed.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product stores sensitive data in memory that is not locked, or that has been incorrectly locked, which might cause the memory to be written to swap files on disk by the virtual memory manager. This can make the data more accessible to external actors.
cwe.name: Sensitive Data Storage in Improperly Locked Memory
cwe.extended_summary: On Windows systems the VirtualLock function can lock a page of memory to ensure that it will remain present in memory and not be swapped to disk. However, on older versions of Windows, such as 95, 98, or Me, the VirtualLock() function is only a stub and provides no protection. On POSIX systems the mlock() call ensures that a page will stay resident in memory but does not guarantee that the page will not appear in the swap. Therefore, it is unsuitable for use as a protection mechanism for sensitive data. Some platforms, in particular Linux, do make the guarantee that the page will not be swapped, but this is non-standard and is not portable. Calls to mlock() also require supervisor privilege. Return values for both of these calls must be checked to ensure that the lock operation was actually successful.

cwe.description: This weakness has been deprecated because it covered redundant concepts already described in CWE-287.
cwe.summary: This weakness has been deprecated because it covered redundant concepts already described in CWE-287.
cwe.name: DEPRECATED: Authentication Bypass Issues

cwe.description: The product modifies the SSL context after connection creation has begun.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Bypass Protection Mechanism</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>No authentication takes place in this process, bypassing an assumed protection of encryption.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>The encrypted communication between a user and a trusted host may be subject to a sniffing attack.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product modifies the SSL context after connection creation has begun.
cwe.name: Authentication Bypass: OpenSSL CTX Object Modified after SSL Objects are Created
cwe.extended_summary: If the program modifies the SSL_CTX object after creating SSL objects from it, there is the possibility that older SSL objects created from the original context could all be affected by that change.

cwe.description: When the J2EE container attempts to write unserializable objects to disk there is no guarantee that the process will complete successfully.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>Data represented by unserializable objects can be corrupted.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>DoS: Crash, Exit, or Restart</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>Non-serializability of objects can lead to system crash.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: When the J2EE container attempts to write unserializable objects to disk there is no guarantee that the process will complete successfully.
cwe.name: J2EE Framework: Saving Unserializable Objects to Disk
cwe.extended_summary: In heavy load conditions, most J2EE application frameworks flush objects to disk to manage memory requirements of incoming requests. For example, session scoped objects, and even application scoped objects, are written to disk when required. While these application frameworks do the real work of writing objects to disk, they do not enforce that those objects be serializable, thus leaving the web application vulnerable to crashes induced by serialization failure. An attacker may be able to mount a denial of service attack by sending enough requests to the server to force the web application to save objects to disk.

cwe.description: The product compares object references instead of the contents of the objects themselves, preventing it from detecting equivalent objects.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Varies by Context</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>This weakness can lead to erroneous results that can cause unexpected application behaviors.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product compares object references instead of the contents of the objects themselves, preventing it from detecting equivalent objects.
cwe.name: Comparison of Object References Instead of Object Contents
cwe.extended_summary: For example, in Java, comparing objects using == usually produces deceptive results, since the == operator compares object references rather than values; often, this means that using == for strings is actually comparing the strings' references, not their values.

cwe.description: This weakness has been deprecated.  It was poorly described and difficult to distinguish from other entries.  It was also inappropriate to assign a separate ID solely because of domain-specific considerations.  Its closest equivalent is CWE-1023.
cwe.summary: This weakness has been deprecated.  It was poorly described and difficult to distinguish from other entries.  It was also inappropriate to assign a separate ID solely because of domain-specific considerations.  Its closest equivalent is CWE-1023.
cwe.name: DEPRECATED: Incorrect Semantic Object Comparison

cwe.description: The product uses the wrong operator when comparing a string, such as using "==" when the .equals() method should be used instead.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Other</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product uses the wrong operator when comparing a string, such as using "==" when the .equals() method should be used instead.
cwe.name: Use of Wrong Operator in String Comparison
cwe.extended_summary: In Java, using == or != to compare two strings for equality actually compares two objects for equality rather than their string values for equality. Chances are good that the two references will never be equal. While this weakness often only affects program correctness, if the equality is used for a security decision, the unintended comparison result could be leveraged to affect program security.

cwe.description: The web application uses the HTTP GET method to process a request and includes sensitive information in the query string of that request.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>At a minimum, attackers can garner information from query strings that can be utilized in escalating their method of attack, such as information about the internal workings of the application or database column names. Successful exploitation of query string parameter vulnerabilities could lead to an attacker impersonating a legitimate user, obtaining proprietary data, or simply executing actions not intended by the application developers.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The web application uses the HTTP GET method to process a request and includes sensitive information in the query string of that request.
cwe.name: Use of GET Request Method With Sensitive Query Strings
cwe.extended_summary: The query string for the URL could be saved in the browser's history, passed through Referers to other web sites, stored in web logs, or otherwise recorded in other sources.  If the query string contains sensitive information such as session identifiers, then attackers can use this information to launch further attacks.

cwe.description: The product uses OpenSSL and trusts or uses a certificate without using the SSL_get_verify_result() function to ensure that the certificate satisfies all necessary security requirements.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>The data read may not be properly secured, it might be viewed by an attacker.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Bypass Protection Mechanism</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>Trust afforded to the system in question may allow for spoofing or redirection attacks.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>If the certificate is not checked, it may be possible for a redirection or spoofing attack to allow a malicious host with a valid certificate to provide data under the guise of a trusted host. While the attacker in question may have a valid certificate, it may simply be a valid certificate for a different site. In order to ensure data integrity, we must check that the certificate is valid, and that it pertains to the site we wish to access.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product uses OpenSSL and trusts or uses a certificate without using the SSL_get_verify_result() function to ensure that the certificate satisfies all necessary security requirements.
cwe.name: Missing Validation of OpenSSL Certificate
cwe.extended_summary: This could allow an attacker to use an invalid certificate to claim to be a trusted host, use expired certificates, or conduct other attacks that could be detected if the certificate is properly validated.

cwe.description: The J2EE application is configured to use an insufficient session ID length.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>If an attacker can guess an authenticated user's session identifier, they can take over the user's session.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The J2EE application is configured to use an insufficient session ID length.
cwe.name: J2EE Misconfiguration: Insufficient Session-ID Length
cwe.extended_summary: If an attacker can guess or steal a session ID, then they may be able to take over the user's session (called session hijacking). The number of possible session IDs increases with increased session ID length, making it more difficult to guess or steal a session ID.

cwe.description: The Servlet does not catch all exceptions, which may reveal sensitive debugging information.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>DoS: Crash, Exit, or Restart</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The Servlet does not catch all exceptions, which may reveal sensitive debugging information.
cwe.name: Uncaught Exception in Servlet
cwe.extended_summary: When a Servlet throws an exception, the default error response the Servlet container sends back to the user typically includes debugging information. This information is of great value to an attacker. For example, a stack trace might show the attacker a malformed SQL query string, the type of database being used, and the version of the application container. This information enables the attacker to target known vulnerabilities in these components.

cwe.description: A web application accepts a user-controlled input that specifies a link to an external site, and uses that link in a Redirect. This simplifies phishing attacks.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Bypass Protection Mechanism</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>The user may be redirected to an untrusted page that contains malware which may then compromise the user's machine. This will expose the user to extensive risk and the user's interaction with the web server may also be compromised if the malware conducts keylogging or other attacks that steal credentials, personally identifiable information (PII), or other important data.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Bypass Protection Mechanism</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Other</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>The user may be subjected to phishing attacks by being redirected to an untrusted page. The phishing attack may point to an attacker controlled web page that appears to be a trusted web site. The phishers may then steal the user's credentials and then use these credentials to access the legitimate web site.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: A web application accepts a user-controlled input that specifies a link to an external site, and uses that link in a Redirect. This simplifies phishing attacks.
cwe.name: URL Redirection to Untrusted Site ('Open Redirect')
cwe.extended_summary: An http parameter may contain a URL value and could cause the web application to redirect the request to the specified URL. By modifying the URL value to a malicious site, an attacker may successfully launch a phishing scam and steal user credentials. Because the server name in the modified link is identical to the original site, phishing attempts have a more trustworthy appearance. Whether this issue poses a vulnerability will be subject to the intended behavior of the application. For example, a search engine might intentionally provide redirects to arbitrary URLs.

cwe.description: The product is composed of a server that relies on the client to implement a mechanism that is intended to protect the server.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Bypass Protection Mechanism</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>DoS: Crash, Exit, or Restart</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>Client-side validation checks can be easily bypassed, allowing malformed or unexpected input to pass into the application, potentially as trusted data. This may lead to unexpected states, behaviors and possibly a resulting crash.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
