               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Bypass Protection Mechanism</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>Client-side checks for authentication can be easily bypassed, allowing clients to escalate their access levels and perform unintended actions.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product is composed of a server that relies on the client to implement a mechanism that is intended to protect the server.
cwe.name: Client-Side Enforcement of Server-Side Security
cwe.extended_summary: When the server relies on protection mechanisms placed on the client side, an attacker can modify the client-side behavior to bypass the protection mechanisms, resulting in potentially unexpected interactions between the client and server. The consequences will vary, depending on what the mechanisms are trying to protect.

cwe.description: A client/server product performs authentication within client code but not in server code, allowing server-side authentication to be bypassed via a modified client that omits the authentication check.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Bypass Protection Mechanism</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: A client/server product performs authentication within client code but not in server code, allowing server-side authentication to be bypassed via a modified client that omits the authentication check.
cwe.name: Use of Client-Side Authentication
cwe.extended_summary: Client-side authentication is extremely weak and may be breached easily. Any attacker may read the source code and reverse-engineer the authentication mechanism to access parts of the application which would otherwise be protected.

cwe.description: When multiple sockets are allowed to bind to the same port, other services on that port may be stolen or spoofed.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>Packets from a variety of network services may be stolen or the services spoofed.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: When multiple sockets are allowed to bind to the same port, other services on that port may be stolen or spoofed.
cwe.name: Multiple Binds to the Same Port
cwe.extended_summary: On most systems, a combination of setting the SO_REUSEADDR socket option, and a call to bind() allows any process to bind to a port to which a previous process has bound with INADDR_ANY. This allows a user to bind to the specific address of a server bound to INADDR_ANY on an unprivileged port, and steal its UDP packets/TCP connection.

cwe.description: The product does not properly check inputs that are used for loop conditions, potentially leading to a denial of service or other consequences because of excessive looping.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>DoS: Resource Consumption (CPU)</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product does not properly check inputs that are used for loop conditions, potentially leading to a denial of service or other consequences because of excessive looping.
cwe.name: Unchecked Input for Loop Condition

cwe.description: A public or protected static final field references a mutable object, which allows the object to be changed by malicious code, or accidentally from another package.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Application Data</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: A public or protected static final field references a mutable object, which allows the object to be changed by malicious code, or accidentally from another package.
cwe.name: Public Static Final Field References Mutable Object

cwe.description: An ActionForm class contains a field that has not been declared private, which can be accessed without using a setter or getter.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: An ActionForm class contains a field that has not been declared private, which can be accessed without using a setter or getter.
cwe.name: Struts: Non-private Field in ActionForm Class

cwe.description: The product uses double-checked locking to access a resource without the overhead of explicit synchronization, but the locking is insufficient.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Alter Execution Logic</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product uses double-checked locking to access a resource without the overhead of explicit synchronization, but the locking is insufficient.
cwe.name: Double-Checked Locking
cwe.extended_summary: Double-checked locking refers to the situation where a programmer checks to see if a resource has been initialized, grabs a lock, checks again to see if the resource has been initialized, and then performs the initialization if it has not occurred yet. This should not be done, as it is not guaranteed to work in all languages and on all architectures. In summary, other threads may not be operating inside the synchronous block and are not guaranteed to see the operations execute in the same order as they would appear inside the synchronous block.

cwe.description: The product, when opening a file or directory, does not sufficiently account for when the file is a symbolic link that resolves to a target outside of the intended control sphere. This could allow an attacker to cause the product to operate on unauthorized files.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product, when opening a file or directory, does not sufficiently account for when the file is a symbolic link that resolves to a target outside of the intended control sphere. This could allow an attacker to cause the product to operate on unauthorized files.
cwe.name: UNIX Symbolic Link (Symlink) Following
cwe.extended_summary: A product that allows UNIX symbolic links (symlink) as part of paths whether in internal code or through user input can allow an attacker to spoof the symbolic link and traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files. The symbolic link can permit an attacker to read/write/corrupt a file that they originally did not have permissions to access.

cwe.description: The product uses an externally controlled name or reference that resolves to a resource that is outside of the intended control sphere.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Application Data</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
	 '
cwe.summary: The product uses an externally controlled name or reference that resolves to a resource that is outside of the intended control sphere.
cwe.name: Externally Controlled Reference to a Resource in Another Sphere

cwe.description: The product processes an XML document that can contain XML entities with URIs that resolve to documents outside of the intended sphere of control, causing the product to embed incorrect documents into its output.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>If the attacker is able to include a crafted DTD and a default entity resolver is enabled, the attacker may be able to access arbitrary files on the system.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Bypass Protection Mechanism</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>The DTD may include arbitrary HTTP requests that the server may execute. This could lead to other attacks leveraging the server's trust relationship with other entities.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>DoS: Resource Consumption (CPU)</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>DoS: Resource Consumption (Memory)</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>The product could consume excessive CPU cycles or memory using a URI that points to a large file, or a device that always returns data such as /dev/random. Alternately, the URI could reference a file that contains many nested or recursive entity references to further slow down parsing.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product processes an XML document that can contain XML entities with URIs that resolve to documents outside of the intended sphere of control, causing the product to embed incorrect documents into its output.
cwe.name: Improper Restriction of XML External Entity Reference
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <html:p>XML documents optionally contain a Document Type Definition (DTD), which, among other features, enables the definition of XML entities. It is possible to define an entity by providing a substitution string in the form of a URI. The XML parser can access the contents of this URI and embed these contents back into the XML document for further processing.</html:p>
            <html:p>By submitting an XML file that defines an external entity with a file:// URI, an attacker can cause the processing application to read the contents of a local file. For example, a URI such as "file:///c:/winnt/win.ini" designates (in Windows) the file C:\Winnt\win.ini, or file:///etc/passwd designates the password file in Unix-based systems. Using URIs with other schemes such as http://, the attacker can force the application to make outgoing requests to servers that the attacker cannot reach directly, which can be used to bypass firewall restrictions or hide the source of attacks such as port scanning.</html:p>
            <html:p>Once the content of the URI is read, it is fed back into the application that is processing the XML. This application may echo back the data (e.g. in an error message), thereby exposing the file contents.</html:p>
         </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: The product creates a search index of private or sensitive documents, but it does not properly limit index access to actors who are authorized to see the original information.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
	 '
cwe.summary: The product creates a search index of private or sensitive documents, but it does not properly limit index access to actors who are authorized to see the original information.
cwe.name: Improper Authorization of Index Containing Sensitive Information
cwe.extended_summary: Web sites and other document repositories may apply an indexing routine against a group of private documents to facilitate search.  If the index's results are available to parties who do not have access to the documents being indexed, then attackers could obtain portions of the documents by conducting targeted searches and reading the results.  The risk is especially dangerous if search results include surrounding text that was not part of the search query. This issue can appear in search engines that are not configured (or implemented) to ignore critical files that should remain hidden; even without permissions to download these files directly, the remote user could read them.

cwe.description: According to WASC, "Insufficient Session Expiration is when a web site permits an attacker to reuse old session credentials or session IDs for authorization."
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Bypass Protection Mechanism</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: According to WASC, "Insufficient Session Expiration is when a web site permits an attacker to reuse old session credentials or session IDs for authorization."
cwe.name: Insufficient Session Expiration

cwe.description: The Secure attribute for sensitive cookies in HTTPS sessions is not set, which could cause the user agent to send those cookies in plaintext over an HTTP session.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The Secure attribute for sensitive cookies in HTTPS sessions is not set, which could cause the user agent to send those cookies in plaintext over an HTTP session.
cwe.name: Sensitive Cookie in HTTPS Session Without 'Secure' Attribute

cwe.description: While adding general comments is very useful, some programmers tend to leave important data, such as: filenames related to the web application, old links or links which were not meant to be browsed by users, old code fragments, etc.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: While adding general comments is very useful, some programmers tend to leave important data, such as: filenames related to the web application, old links or links which were not meant to be browsed by users, old code fragments, etc.
cwe.name: Inclusion of Sensitive Information in Source Code Comments
cwe.extended_summary: An attacker who finds these comments can map the application's structure and files, expose hidden parts of the site, and study the fragments of code to reverse engineer the application, which may help develop further attacks against the site.

cwe.description: The PHP application uses an old method for processing uploaded files by referencing the four global variables that are set for each file (e.g. $varname, $varname_size, $varname_name, $varname_type). These variables could be overwritten by attackers, causing the application to process unauthorized files.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The PHP application uses an old method for processing uploaded files by referencing the four global variables that are set for each file (e.g. $varname, $varname_size, $varname_name, $varname_type). These variables could be overwritten by attackers, causing the application to process unauthorized files.
cwe.name: Incomplete Identification of Uploaded File Variables (PHP)
cwe.extended_summary: These global variables could be overwritten by POST requests, cookies, or other methods of populating or overwriting these variables. This could be used to read or process arbitrary files by providing values such as "/etc/passwd".

cwe.description: The product contains an assert() or similar statement that can be triggered by an attacker, which leads to an application exit or other behavior that is more severe than necessary.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>DoS: Crash, Exit, or Restart</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>An attacker that can trigger an assert statement can still lead to a denial of service if the relevant code can be triggered by an attacker, and if the scope of the assert() extends beyond the attacker's own session.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product contains an assert() or similar statement that can be triggered by an attacker, which leads to an application exit or other behavior that is more severe than necessary.
cwe.name: Reachable Assertion
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <html:p>While assertion is good for catching logic errors and reducing the chances of reaching more serious vulnerability conditions, it can still lead to a denial of service.</html:p>
            <html:p>For example, if a server handles multiple simultaneous connections, and an assert() occurs in one single connection that causes all other connections to be dropped, this is a reachable assertion that leads to a denial of service.</html:p>
         </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: An ActiveX control is intended for use in a web browser, but it exposes dangerous methods that perform actions that are outside of the browser's security model (e.g. the zone or domain).
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Other</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: An ActiveX control is intended for use in a web browser, but it exposes dangerous methods that perform actions that are outside of the browser's security model (e.g. the zone or domain).
cwe.name: Exposed Unsafe ActiveX Method
cwe.extended_summary: ActiveX controls can exercise far greater control over the operating system than typical Java or javascript. Exposed methods can be subject to various vulnerabilities, depending on the implemented behaviors of those methods, and whether input validation is performed on the provided arguments. If there is no integrity checking or origin validation, this method could be invoked by attackers.

cwe.description: If a database cursor is not closed properly, then it could become accessible to other users while retaining the same privileges that were originally assigned, leaving the cursor "dangling."
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Application Data</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: If a database cursor is not closed properly, then it could become accessible to other users while retaining the same privileges that were originally assigned, leaving the cursor "dangling."
cwe.name: Dangling Database Cursor ('Cursor Injection')
cwe.extended_summary: For example, an improper dangling cursor could arise from unhandled exceptions. The impact of the issue depends on the cursor's role, but SQL injection attacks are commonly possible.

cwe.description: The product, when opening a file or directory, does not sufficiently account for when the name is associated with a hard link to a target that is outside of the intended control sphere. This could allow an attacker to cause the product to operate on unauthorized files.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product, when opening a file or directory, does not sufficiently account for when the name is associated with a hard link to a target that is outside of the intended control sphere. This could allow an attacker to cause the product to operate on unauthorized files.
cwe.name: UNIX Hard Link
cwe.extended_summary: Failure for a system to check for hard links can result in vulnerability to different types of attacks. For example, an attacker can escalate their privileges if a file used by a privileged program is replaced with a hard link to a sensitive file (e.g. /etc/passwd). When the process opens the file, the attacker can assume the privileges of that process.

cwe.description: When setting a new password for a user, the product does not require knowledge of the original password, or using another form of authentication.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Bypass Protection Mechanism</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: When setting a new password for a user, the product does not require knowledge of the original password, or using another form of authentication.
cwe.name: Unverified Password Change
cwe.extended_summary: This could be used by an attacker to change passwords for another user, thus gaining the privileges associated with that user.

cwe.description: The product uses external input to determine the names of variables into which information is extracted, without verifying that the names of the specified variables are valid. This could cause the program to overwrite unintended variables.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>An attacker could modify sensitive data or program variables.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product uses external input to determine the names of variables into which information is extracted, without verifying that the names of the specified variables are valid. This could cause the program to overwrite unintended variables.
cwe.name: Variable Extraction Error
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <html:p>For example, in PHP, extraction can be used to provide functionality similar to register_globals, a dangerous functionality that is frequently disabled in production systems. Calling extract() or import_request_variables() without the proper arguments could allow arbitrary global variables to be overwritten, including superglobals.</html:p>
            <html:p>Similar functionality is possible in other interpreted languages, including custom languages.</html:p>
         </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: The product adds hooks to user-accessible API functions, but it does not properly validate the arguments. This could lead to resultant vulnerabilities.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Unexpected State</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product adds hooks to user-accessible API functions, but it does not properly validate the arguments. This could lead to resultant vulnerabilities.
cwe.name: Improper Validation of Function Hook Arguments
cwe.extended_summary: Such hooks can be used in defensive software that runs with privileges, such as anti-virus or firewall, which hooks kernel calls. When the arguments are not validated, they could be used to bypass the protection scheme or attack the product itself.

cwe.description: An ActiveX control is intended for restricted use, but it has been marked as safe-for-scripting.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Execute Unauthorized Code or Commands</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: An ActiveX control is intended for restricted use, but it has been marked as safe-for-scripting.
cwe.name: Unsafe ActiveX Control Marked Safe For Scripting
cwe.extended_summary: This might allow attackers to use dangerous functionality via a web page that accesses the control, which can lead to different resultant vulnerabilities, depending on the control's behavior.

cwe.description: The product uses a regular expression that either (1) contains an executable component with user-controlled inputs, or (2) allows a user to enable execution by inserting pattern modifiers.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Execute Unauthorized Code or Commands</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product uses a regular expression that either (1) contains an executable component with user-controlled inputs, or (2) allows a user to enable execution by inserting pattern modifiers.
cwe.name: Executable Regular Expression Error
cwe.extended_summary: Case (2) is possible in the PHP preg_replace() function, and possibly in other languages when a user-controlled input is inserted into a string that is later parsed as a regular expression.

cwe.description: The product uses a regular expression that does not sufficiently restrict the set of allowed values.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Bypass Protection Mechanism</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product uses a regular expression that does not sufficiently restrict the set of allowed values.
cwe.name: Permissive Regular Expression
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <html:p>This effectively causes the regexp to accept substrings that match the pattern, which produces a partial comparison to the target. In some cases, this can lead to other weaknesses. Common errors include:</html:p>
               <html:ul>
                  <html:li>not identifying the beginning and end of the target string</html:li>
                  <html:li>using wildcards instead of acceptable character ranges</html:li>
                  <html:li>others</html:li>
               </html:ul>
         </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: The product does not properly handle null bytes or NUL characters when passing data between different representations or components.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Unexpected State</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product does not properly handle null bytes or NUL characters when passing data between different representations or components.
cwe.name: Null Byte Interaction Error (Poison Null Byte)
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <html:p>A null byte (NUL character) can have different meanings across representations or languages. For example, it is a string terminator in standard C libraries, but Perl and PHP strings do not treat it as a terminator. When two representations are crossed - such as when Perl or PHP invokes underlying C functionality - this can produce an interaction error with unexpected results. Similar issues have been reported for ASP. Other interpreters written in C might also be affected.</html:p>
            <html:p>The poison null byte is frequently useful in path traversal attacks by terminating hard-coded extensions that are added to a filename. It can play a role in regular expression processing in PHP.</html:p>
         </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: In a language where the user can influence the name of a variable at runtime, if the variable names are not controlled, an attacker can read or write to arbitrary variables, or access arbitrary functions.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Execute Unauthorized Code or Commands</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>An attacker could gain unauthorized access to internal program variables and execute arbitrary code.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: In a language where the user can influence the name of a variable at runtime, if the variable names are not controlled, an attacker can read or write to arbitrary variables, or access arbitrary functions.
cwe.name: Dynamic Variable Evaluation
cwe.extended_summary: The resultant vulnerabilities depend on the behavior of the application, both at the crossover point and in any control/data flow that is reachable by the related variables or functions.

cwe.description: The product calls a function, procedure, or routine with arguments that are not correctly specified, leading to always-incorrect behavior and resultant weaknesses.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Quality Degradation</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>This weakness can cause unintended behavior and can lead to additional weaknesses such as allowing an attacker to gain unintended access to system resources.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product calls a function, procedure, or routine with arguments that are not correctly specified, leading to always-incorrect behavior and resultant weaknesses.
cwe.name: Function Call with Incorrectly Specified Arguments
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <html:p>There are multiple ways in which this weakness can be introduced, including:</html:p>
               <html:ul>
                  <html:li>the wrong variable or reference;</html:li>
                  <html:li>an incorrect number of arguments;</html:li>
                  <html:li>incorrect order of arguments;</html:li>
                  <html:li>wrong type of arguments; or</html:li>
                  <html:li>wrong value.</html:li>
               </html:ul>
         </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: When the product encounters an error condition or failure, its design requires it to fall back to a state that is less secure than other options that are available, such as selecting the weakest encryption algorithm or using the most permissive access control restrictions.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Bypass Protection Mechanism</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>Intended access restrictions can be bypassed, which is often contradictory to what the product's administrator expects.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: When the product encounters an error condition or failure, its design requires it to fall back to a state that is less secure than other options that are available, such as selecting the weakest encryption algorithm or using the most permissive access control restrictions.
cwe.name: Not Failing Securely ('Failing Open')
cwe.extended_summary: By entering a less secure state, the product inherits the weaknesses associated with that state, making it easier to compromise. At the least, it causes administrators to have a false sense of security. This weakness typically occurs as a result of wanting to "fail functional" to minimize administration and support costs, instead of "failing safe."

cwe.description: The product uses a more complex mechanism than necessary, which could lead to resultant weaknesses when the mechanism is not correctly understood, modeled, configured, implemented, or used.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Other</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product uses a more complex mechanism than necessary, which could lead to resultant weaknesses when the mechanism is not correctly understood, modeled, configured, implemented, or used.
cwe.name: Unnecessary Complexity in Protection Mechanism (Not Using 'Economy of Mechanism')
cwe.extended_summary: Security mechanisms should be as simple as possible. Complex security mechanisms may engender partial implementations and compatibility problems, with resulting mismatches in assumptions and implemented security. A corollary of this principle is that data specifications should be as simple as possible, because complex data specifications result in complex validation code. Complex tasks and systems may also need to be guarded by complex security checks, so simple systems should be preferred.

cwe.description: The product does not perform access checks on a resource every time the resource is accessed by an entity, which can create resultant weaknesses if that entity's rights or privileges change over time.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Execute Unauthorized Code or Commands</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Bypass Protection Mechanism</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Other</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>A user might retain access to a critical resource even after privileges have been revoked, possibly allowing access to privileged functionality or sensitive information, depending on the role of the resource.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product does not perform access checks on a resource every time the resource is accessed by an entity, which can create resultant weaknesses if that entity's rights or privileges change over time.
cwe.name: Not Using Complete Mediation

cwe.description: The system's authorization functionality does not prevent one user from gaining access to another user's data or record by modifying the key value identifying the data.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Bypass Protection Mechanism</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>Access control checks for specific user data or functionality can be bypassed.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>Horizontal escalation of privilege is possible (one user can view/modify information of another user).</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>Vertical escalation of privilege is possible if the user-controlled key is actually a flag that indicates administrator status, allowing the attacker to gain administrative access.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The system's authorization functionality does not prevent one user from gaining access to another user's data or record by modifying the key value identifying the data.
cwe.name: Authorization Bypass Through User-Controlled Key
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <html:p>Retrieval of a user record occurs in the system based on some key value that is under user control. The key would typically identify a user-related record stored in the system and would be used to lookup that record for presentation to the user. It is likely that an attacker would have to be an authenticated user in the system. However, the authorization process would not properly check the data access operation to ensure that the authenticated user performing the operation has sufficient entitlements to perform the requested data access, hence bypassing any other authorization checks present in the system.</html:p>
            <html:p>For example, attackers can look at places where user specific data is retrieved (e.g. search screens) and determine whether the key for the item being looked up is controllable externally. The key may be a hidden field in the HTML form field, might be passed as a URL parameter or as an unencrypted cookie variable, then in each of these cases it will be possible to tamper with the key value.</html:p>
            <html:p>One manifestation of this weakness is when a system uses sequential or otherwise easily-guessable session IDs that would allow one user to easily switch to another user's session and read/modify their data.</html:p>
         </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: The product, when opening a file or directory, does not sufficiently handle when the file is a Windows shortcut (.LNK) whose target is outside of the intended control sphere. This could allow an attacker to cause the product to operate on unauthorized files.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product, when opening a file or directory, does not sufficiently handle when the file is a Windows shortcut (.LNK) whose target is outside of the intended control sphere. This could allow an attacker to cause the product to operate on unauthorized files.
cwe.name: Windows Shortcut Following (.LNK)
cwe.extended_summary: The shortcut (file with the .lnk extension) can permit an attacker to read/write a file that they originally did not have permissions to access.

cwe.description: The product contains a mechanism for users to recover or change their passwords without knowing the original password, but the mechanism is weak.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>An attacker could gain unauthorized access to the system by retrieving legitimate user's authentication credentials.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>DoS: Resource Consumption (Other)</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>An attacker could deny service to legitimate system users by launching a brute force attack on the password recovery mechanism using user ids of legitimate users.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Other</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>The system's security functionality is turned against the system by the attacker.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product contains a mechanism for users to recover or change their passwords without knowing the original password, but the mechanism is weak.
cwe.name: Weak Password Recovery Mechanism for Forgotten Password
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <html:p>It is common for an application to have a mechanism that provides a means for a user to gain access to their account in the event they forget their password. Very often the password recovery mechanism is weak, which has the effect of making it more likely that it would be possible for a person other than the legitimate system user to gain access to that user's account. Weak password recovery schemes completely undermine a strong password authentication scheme.</html:p>
            <html:p>This weakness may be that the security question is too easy to guess or find an answer to (e.g. because the question is too common, or the answers can be found using social media). Or there might be an implementation weakness in the password recovery mechanism code that may for instance trick the system into e-mailing the new password to an e-mail account other than that of the user. There might be no throttling done on the rate of password resets so that a legitimate user can be denied service by an attacker if an attacker tries to recover their password in a rapid succession. The system may send the original password to the user rather than generating a new temporary password. In summary, password recovery functionality, if not carefully designed and implemented can often become the system's weakest link that can be misused in a way that would allow an attacker to gain unauthorized access to the system.</html:p>
         </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: The product constructs the name of a file or other resource using input from an upstream component, but it does not restrict or incorrectly restricts the resulting name.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Execute Unauthorized Code or Commands</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>Execution of arbitrary code in the context of usage of the resources with dangerous names.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>DoS: Crash, Exit, or Restart</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>Crash of the consumer code of these resources resulting in information leakage or denial of service.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product constructs the name of a file or other resource using input from an upstream component, but it does not restrict or incorrectly restricts the resulting name.
cwe.name: Improper Restriction of Names for Files and Other Resources
cwe.extended_summary: This may produce resultant weaknesses. For instance, if the names of these resources contain scripting characters, it is possible that a script may get executed in the client's browser if the application ever displays the name of the resource on a dynamically generated web page. Alternately, if the resources are consumed by some application parser, a specially crafted name can exploit some vulnerability internal to the parser, potentially resulting in execution of arbitrary code on the server machine. The problems will vary based on the context of usage of such malformed resource names and whether vulnerabilities are present in or assumptions are made by the targeted technology that would make code execution possible.

cwe.description: The product stores security-critical state information about its users, or the product itself, in a location that is accessible to unauthorized actors.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Bypass Protection Mechanism</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>An attacker could potentially modify the state in malicious ways. If the state is related to the privileges or level of authentication that the user has, then state modification might allow the user to bypass authentication or elevate privileges.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>The state variables may contain sensitive information that should not be known by the client.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>DoS: Crash, Exit, or Restart</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>By modifying state variables, the attacker could violate the application's expectations for the contents of the state, leading to a denial of service due to an unexpected error condition.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product stores security-critical state information about its users, or the product itself, in a location that is accessible to unauthorized actors.
cwe.name: External Control of Critical State Data
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <html:p>If an attacker can modify the state information without detection, then it could be used to perform unauthorized actions or access unexpected resources, since the application programmer does not expect that the state can be changed.</html:p>
            <html:p>State information can be stored in various locations such as a cookie, in a hidden web form field, input parameter or argument, an environment variable, a database record, within a settings file, etc. All of these locations have the potential to be modified by an attacker. When this state information is used to control security or determine resource usage, then it may create a vulnerability. For example, an application may perform authentication, then save the state in an "authenticated=true" cookie. An attacker may simply create this cookie in order to bypass the authentication.</html:p>
         </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: The product uses external input to dynamically construct an XPath expression used to retrieve data from an XML database, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes that input. This allows an attacker to control the structure of the query.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Bypass Protection Mechanism</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>Controlling application flow (e.g. bypassing authentication).</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>The attacker could read restricted XML content.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product uses external input to dynamically construct an XPath expression used to retrieve data from an XML database, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes that input. This allows an attacker to control the structure of the query.
cwe.name: Improper Neutralization of Data within XPath Expressions ('XPath Injection')
cwe.extended_summary: The net effect is that the attacker will have control over the information selected from the XML database and may use that ability to control application flow, modify logic, retrieve unauthorized data, or bypass important checks (e.g. authentication).

cwe.description: The product does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes web scripting syntax in HTTP headers that can be used by web browser components that can process raw headers, such as Flash.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Execute Unauthorized Code or Commands</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>Run arbitrary code.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>Attackers may be able to obtain sensitive information.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes web scripting syntax in HTTP headers that can be used by web browser components that can process raw headers, such as Flash.
cwe.name: Improper Neutralization of HTTP Headers for Scripting Syntax
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <html:p>An attacker may be able to conduct cross-site scripting and other attacks against users who have these components enabled.</html:p>
            <html:p>If a product does not neutralize user controlled data being placed in the header of an HTTP response coming from the server, the header may contain a script that will get executed in the client's browser context, potentially resulting in a cross site scripting vulnerability or possibly an HTTP response splitting attack. It is important to carefully control data that is being placed both in HTTP response header and in the HTTP response body to ensure that no scripting syntax is present, taking various encodings into account.</html:p>
         </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: The product contains an account lockout protection mechanism, but the mechanism is too restrictive and can be triggered too easily, which allows attackers to deny service to legitimate users by causing their accounts to be locked out.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>DoS: Resource Consumption (Other)</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>Users could be locked out of accounts.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product contains an account lockout protection mechanism, but the mechanism is too restrictive and can be triggered too easily, which allows attackers to deny service to legitimate users by causing their accounts to be locked out.
cwe.name: Overly Restrictive Account Lockout Mechanism
cwe.extended_summary: Account lockout is a security feature often present in applications as a countermeasure to the brute force attack on the password based authentication mechanism of the system. After a certain number of failed login attempts, the users' account may be disabled for a certain period of time or until it is unlocked by an administrator. Other security events may also possibly trigger account lockout. However, an attacker may use this very security feature to deny service to legitimate system users. It is therefore important to ensure that the account lockout security mechanism is not overly restrictive.

cwe.description: The product allows a file to be uploaded, but it relies on the file name or extension of the file to determine the appropriate behaviors. This could be used by attackers to cause the file to be misclassified and processed in a dangerous fashion.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>An attacker may be able to read sensitive data.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>DoS: Crash, Exit, or Restart</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>An attacker may be able to cause a denial of service.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>An attacker may be able to gain privileges.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product allows a file to be uploaded, but it relies on the file name or extension of the file to determine the appropriate behaviors. This could be used by attackers to cause the file to be misclassified and processed in a dangerous fashion.
cwe.name: Reliance on File Name or Extension of Externally-Supplied File
cwe.extended_summary: An application might use the file name or extension of a user-supplied file to determine the proper course of action, such as selecting the correct process to which control should be passed, deciding what data should be made available, or what resources should be allocated. If the attacker can cause the code to misclassify the supplied file, then the wrong action could occur. For example, an attacker could supply a file that ends in a ".php.gif" extension that appears to be a GIF image, but would be processed as PHP code. In extreme cases, code execution is possible, but the attacker could also cause exhaustion of resources, denial of service, exposure of debug or system data (including application source code), or being bound to a particular server side process. This weakness may be due to a vulnerability in any of the technologies used by the web and application servers, due to misconfiguration, or resultant from another flaw in the application itself.

cwe.description: The product defines policy namespaces and makes authorization decisions based on the assumption that a URL is canonical. This can allow a non-canonical URL to bypass the authorization.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Bypass Protection Mechanism</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>An attacker may be able to bypass the authorization mechanism to gain access to the otherwise-protected URL.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>If a non-canonical URL is used, the server may choose to return the contents of the file, instead of pre-processing the file (e.g. as a program).</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product defines policy namespaces and makes authorization decisions based on the assumption that a URL is canonical. This can allow a non-canonical URL to bypass the authorization.
cwe.name: Use of Non-Canonical URL Paths for Authorization Decisions
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <html:p>If an application defines policy namespaces and makes authorization decisions based on the URL, but it does not require or convert to a canonical URL before making the authorization decision, then it opens the application to attack. For example, if the application only wants to allow access to http://www.example.com/mypage, then the attacker might be able to bypass this restriction using equivalent URLs such as:</html:p>
               <html:ul>
                  <html:li>http://WWW.EXAMPLE.COM/mypage</html:li>
                  <html:li>http://www.example.com/%6Dypage (alternate encoding)</html:li>
                  <html:li>http://192.168.1.1/mypage (IP address)</html:li>
                  <html:li>http://www.example.com/mypage/ (trailing /)</html:li>
                  <html:li>http://www.example.com:80/mypage</html:li>
               </html:ul>
            <html:p>Therefore it is important to specify access control policy that is based on the path information in some canonical form with all alternate encodings rejected (which can be accomplished by a default deny rule).</html:p>
         </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: The product does not conform to the API requirements for a function call that requires extra privileges. This could allow attackers to gain privileges by causing the function to be called incorrectly.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>An attacker may be able to elevate privileges.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>An attacker may be able to obtain sensitive information.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Execute Unauthorized Code or Commands</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>An attacker may be able to execute code.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product does not conform to the API requirements for a function call that requires extra privileges. This could allow attackers to gain privileges by causing the function to be called incorrectly.
cwe.name: Incorrect Use of Privileged APIs
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <html:p>When a product contains certain functions that perform operations requiring an elevated level of privilege, the caller of a privileged API must be careful to:</html:p>
               <html:ul>
                  <html:li>ensure that assumptions made by the APIs are valid, such as validity of arguments</html:li>
                  <html:li>account for known weaknesses in the design/implementation of the API</html:li>
                  <html:li>call the API from a safe context</html:li>
               </html:ul>
            <html:p>If the caller of the API does not follow these requirements, then it may allow a malicious user or process to elevate their privilege, hijack the process, or steal sensitive data.</html:p>
            <html:p>For instance, it is important to know if privileged APIs do not shed their privileges before returning to the caller or if the privileged function might make certain assumptions about the data, context or state information passed to it by the caller. It is important to always know when and how privileged APIs can be called in order to ensure that their elevated level of privilege cannot be exploited.</html:p>
         </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: The product uses obfuscation or encryption of inputs that should not be mutable by an external actor, but the product does not use integrity checks to detect if those inputs have been modified.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Unexpected State</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>The inputs could be modified without detection, causing the product to have unexpected system state or make incorrect security decisions.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product uses obfuscation or encryption of inputs that should not be mutable by an external actor, but the product does not use integrity checks to detect if those inputs have been modified.
cwe.name: Reliance on Obfuscation or Encryption of Security-Relevant Inputs without Integrity Checking
cwe.extended_summary: When an application relies on obfuscation or incorrectly applied / weak encryption to protect client-controllable tokens or parameters, that may have an effect on the user state, system state, or some decision made on the server. Without protecting the tokens/parameters for integrity, the application is vulnerable to an attack where an adversary traverses the space of possible values of the said token/parameter in order to attempt to gain an advantage. The goal of the attacker is to find another admissible value that will somehow elevate their privileges in the system, disclose information or change the behavior of the system in some way beneficial to the attacker. If the application does not protect these critical tokens/parameters for integrity, it will not be able to determine that these values have been tampered with. Measures that are used to protect data for confidentiality should not be relied upon to provide the integrity service.

cwe.description: The product, when opening a file or directory, does not sufficiently handle when the name is associated with a hard link to a target that is outside of the intended control sphere. This could allow an attacker to cause the product to operate on unauthorized files.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product, when opening a file or directory, does not sufficiently handle when the name is associated with a hard link to a target that is outside of the intended control sphere. This could allow an attacker to cause the product to operate on unauthorized files.
cwe.name: Windows Hard Link
cwe.extended_summary: Failure for a system to check for hard links can result in vulnerability to different types of attacks. For example, an attacker can escalate their privileges if a file used by a privileged program is replaced with a hard link to a sensitive file (e.g. AUTOEXEC.BAT). When the process opens the file, the attacker can assume the privileges of that process, or prevent the program from accurately processing data.

cwe.description: The server contains a protection mechanism that assumes that any URI that is accessed using HTTP GET will not cause a state change to the associated resource. This might allow attackers to bypass intended access restrictions and conduct resource modification and deletion attacks, since some applications allow GET to modify state.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>An attacker could escalate privileges.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>An attacker could modify resources.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>An attacker could obtain sensitive information.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The server contains a protection mechanism that assumes that any URI that is accessed using HTTP GET will not cause a state change to the associated resource. This might allow attackers to bypass intended access restrictions and conduct resource modification and deletion attacks, since some applications allow GET to modify state.
cwe.name: Trusting HTTP Permission Methods on the Server Side
cwe.extended_summary: The HTTP GET method and some other methods are designed to retrieve resources and not to alter the state of the application or resources on the server side. Furthermore, the HTTP specification requires that GET requests (and other requests) should not have side effects. Believing that it will be enough to prevent unintended resource alterations, an application may disallow the HTTP requests to perform DELETE, PUT and POST operations on the resource representation. However, there is nothing in the HTTP protocol itself that actually prevents the HTTP GET method from performing more than just query of the data. Developers can easily code programs that accept a HTTP GET request that do in fact create, update or delete data on the server. For instance, it is a common practice with REST based Web Services to have HTTP GET requests modifying resources on the server side. However, whenever that happens, the access control needs to be properly enforced in the application. No assumptions should be made that only HTTP DELETE, PUT, POST, and other methods have the power to alter the representation of the resource being accessed in the request.

cwe.description: The Web services architecture may require exposing a Web Service Definition Language (WSDL) file that contains information on the publicly accessible services and how callers of these services should interact with them (e.g. what parameters they expect and what types they return).
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>The attacker may find sensitive information located in the WSDL file.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The Web services architecture may require exposing a Web Service Definition Language (WSDL) file that contains information on the publicly accessible services and how callers of these services should interact with them (e.g. what parameters they expect and what types they return).
cwe.name: Exposure of WSDL File Containing Sensitive Information
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <html:p>An information exposure may occur if any of the following apply:</html:p>
               <html:ul>
                  <html:li>The WSDL file is accessible to a wider audience than intended.</html:li>
                  <html:li>The WSDL file contains information on the methods/services that should not be publicly accessible or information about deprecated methods. This problem is made more likely due to the WSDL often being automatically generated from the code.</html:li>
                  <html:li>Information in the WSDL file helps guess names/locations of methods/resources that should not be publicly accessible.</html:li>
               </html:ul>
         </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: The product uses external input to dynamically construct an XQuery expression used to retrieve data from an XML database, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes that input. This allows an attacker to control the structure of the query.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>An attacker might be able to read sensitive information from the XML database.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product uses external input to dynamically construct an XQuery expression used to retrieve data from an XML database, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes that input. This allows an attacker to control the structure of the query.
cwe.name: Improper Neutralization of Data within XQuery Expressions ('XQuery Injection')
cwe.extended_summary: The net effect is that the attacker will have control over the information selected from the XML database and may use that ability to control application flow, modify logic, retrieve unauthorized data, or bypass important checks (e.g. authentication).

cwe.description: The product does not properly compartmentalize or isolate functionality, processes, or resources that require different privilege levels, rights, or permissions.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Bypass Protection Mechanism</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>The exploitation of a weakness in low-privileged areas of the software can be leveraged to reach higher-privileged areas without having to overcome any additional obstacles.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product does not properly compartmentalize or isolate functionality, processes, or resources that require different privilege levels, rights, or permissions.
cwe.name: Improper Isolation or Compartmentalization
cwe.extended_summary: When a weakness occurs in functionality that is accessible by lower-privileged users, then without strong boundaries, an attack might extend the scope of the damage to higher-privileged users.

cwe.description: A protection mechanism relies exclusively, or to a large extent, on the evaluation of a single condition or the integrity of a single object or entity in order to make a decision about granting access to restricted resources or functionality.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>If the single factor is compromised (e.g. by theft or spoofing), then the integrity of the entire security mechanism can be violated with respect to the user that is identified by that factor.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Non-Repudiation</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Hide Activities</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>It can become difficult or impossible for the product to be able to distinguish between legitimate activities by the entity who provided the factor, versus illegitimate activities by an attacker.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: A protection mechanism relies exclusively, or to a large extent, on the evaluation of a single condition or the integrity of a single object or entity in order to make a decision about granting access to restricted resources or functionality.
cwe.name: Reliance on a Single Factor in a Security Decision

cwe.description: The product has a protection mechanism that is too difficult or inconvenient to use, encouraging non-malicious users to disable or bypass the mechanism, whether by accident or on purpose.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Bypass Protection Mechanism</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>By bypassing the security mechanism, a user might leave the system in a less secure state than intended by the administrator, making it more susceptible to compromise.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product has a protection mechanism that is too difficult or inconvenient to use, encouraging non-malicious users to disable or bypass the mechanism, whether by accident or on purpose.
cwe.name: Insufficient Psychological Acceptability

cwe.description: The product uses a protection mechanism whose strength depends heavily on its obscurity, such that knowledge of its algorithms or key data is sufficient to defeat the mechanism.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Other</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>The security mechanism can be bypassed easily.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product uses a protection mechanism whose strength depends heavily on its obscurity, such that knowledge of its algorithms or key data is sufficient to defeat the mechanism.
cwe.name: Reliance on Security Through Obscurity
cwe.extended_summary: This reliance on "security through obscurity" can produce resultant weaknesses if an attacker is able to reverse engineer the inner workings of the mechanism. Note that obscurity can be one small part of defense in depth, since it can create more work for an attacker; however, it is a significant risk if used as the primary means of protection.

cwe.description: The product violates well-established principles for secure design.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Other</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product violates well-established principles for secure design.
cwe.name: Violation of Secure Design Principles
