cwe.extended_summary: This can introduce resultant weaknesses or make it easier for developers to introduce related weaknesses during implementation. Because code is centered around design, it can be resource-intensive to fix design problems.

cwe.description: The product does not handle or incorrectly handles a file name that identifies a "virtual" resource that is not directly specified within the directory that is associated with the file name, causing the product to perform file-based operations on a resource that is not a file.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Other</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product does not handle or incorrectly handles a file name that identifies a "virtual" resource that is not directly specified within the directory that is associated with the file name, causing the product to perform file-based operations on a resource that is not a file.
cwe.name: Improper Handling of File Names that Identify Virtual Resources
cwe.extended_summary: Virtual file names are represented like normal file names, but they are effectively aliases for other resources that do not behave like normal files. Depending on their functionality, they could be alternate entities. They are not necessarily listed in directories.

cwe.description: The product utilizes multiple threads or processes to allow temporary access to a shared resource that can only be exclusive to one process at a time, but it does not properly synchronize these actions, which might cause simultaneous accesses of this resource by multiple threads or processes.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Alter Execution Logic</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product utilizes multiple threads or processes to allow temporary access to a shared resource that can only be exclusive to one process at a time, but it does not properly synchronize these actions, which might cause simultaneous accesses of this resource by multiple threads or processes.
cwe.name: Improper Synchronization
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
	   <html:p>Synchronization refers to a variety of behaviors and mechanisms that allow two or more independently-operating processes or threads to ensure that they operate on shared resources in predictable ways that do not interfere with each other.  Some shared resource operations cannot be executed atomically; that is, multiple steps must be guaranteed to execute sequentially, without any interference by other processes.  Synchronization mechanisms vary widely, but they may include locking, mutexes, and semaphores.  When a multi-step operation on a shared resource cannot be guaranteed to execute independent of interference, then the resulting behavior can be unpredictable. Improper synchronization could lead to data or memory corruption, denial of service, etc.</html:p>
	 </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: The product calls a non-reentrant function in a concurrent context in which a competing code sequence (e.g. thread or signal handler) may have an opportunity to call the same function or otherwise influence its state.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Memory</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Memory</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Alter Execution Logic</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product calls a non-reentrant function in a concurrent context in which a competing code sequence (e.g. thread or signal handler) may have an opportunity to call the same function or otherwise influence its state.
cwe.name: Use of a Non-reentrant Function in a Concurrent Context

cwe.description: The product does not maintain or incorrectly maintains control over a resource throughout its lifetime of creation, use, and release.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Other</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product does not maintain or incorrectly maintains control over a resource throughout its lifetime of creation, use, and release.
cwe.name: Improper Control of a Resource Through its Lifetime
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <html:p>Resources often have explicit instructions on how to be created, used and destroyed. When code does not follow these instructions, it can lead to unexpected behaviors and potentially exploitable states.</html:p>
            <html:p>Even without explicit instructions, various principles are expected to be adhered to, such as "Do not use an object until after its creation is complete," or "do not use an object after it has been slated for destruction."</html:p>
         </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: The product does not initialize or incorrectly initializes a resource, which might leave the resource in an unexpected state when it is accessed or used.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Memory</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>When reusing a resource such as memory or a program variable, the original contents of that resource may not be cleared before it is sent to an untrusted party.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Bypass Protection Mechanism</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>If security-critical decisions rely on a variable having a "0" or equivalent value, and the programming language performs this initialization on behalf of the programmer, then a bypass of security may occur.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>DoS: Crash, Exit, or Restart</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>The uninitialized data may contain values that cause program flow to change in ways that the programmer did not intend. For example, if an uninitialized variable is used as an array index in C, then its previous contents may produce an index that is outside the range of the array, possibly causing a crash or an exit in other environments.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product does not initialize or incorrectly initializes a resource, which might leave the resource in an unexpected state when it is accessed or used.
cwe.name: Improper Initialization
cwe.extended_summary: This can have security implications when the associated resource is expected to have certain properties or values, such as a variable that determines whether a user has been authenticated or not.

cwe.description: The product performs an operation on a resource at the wrong phase of the resource's lifecycle, which can lead to unexpected behaviors.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Other</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product performs an operation on a resource at the wrong phase of the resource's lifecycle, which can lead to unexpected behaviors.
cwe.name: Operation on Resource in Wrong Phase of Lifetime
cwe.extended_summary: A resource's lifecycle includes several phases: initialization, use, and release. For each phase, it is important to follow the specifications outlined for how to operate on the resource and to ensure that the resource is in the expected phase. Otherwise, if a resource is in one phase but the operation is not valid for that phase (i.e., an incorrect phase of the resource's lifetime), then this can produce resultant weaknesses. For example, using a resource before it has been fully initialized could cause corruption or incorrect data to be used.

cwe.description: The product does not properly acquire or release a lock on a resource, leading to unexpected resource state changes and behaviors.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>DoS: Resource Consumption (CPU)</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>Inconsistent locking discipline can lead to deadlock.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product does not properly acquire or release a lock on a resource, leading to unexpected resource state changes and behaviors.
cwe.name: Improper Locking
cwe.extended_summary: b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">\n\t   <html:p>Locking is a type of synchronization behavior that ensures that multiple independently-operating processes or threads do not interfere with each other when accessing the same resource. All processes/threads are expected to follow the same steps for locking. If these steps are not followed precisely - or if no locking is done at all - then another process/thread could modify the shared resource in a way that is not visible or predictable to the original process.  This can lead to data or memory corruption, denial of service, etc.</html:p></ns0:Extended_Description>\n         '

cwe.description: The product exposes a resource to the wrong control sphere, providing unintended actors with inappropriate access to the resource.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Other</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product exposes a resource to the wrong control sphere, providing unintended actors with inappropriate access to the resource.
cwe.name: Exposure of Resource to Wrong Sphere
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <html:p>Resources such as files and directories may be inadvertently exposed through mechanisms such as insecure permissions, or when a program accidentally operates on the wrong object. For example, a program may intend that private files can only be provided to a specific user. This effectively defines a control sphere that is intended to prevent attackers from accessing these private files. If the file permissions are insecure, then parties other than the user will be able to access those files.</html:p>
            <html:p>A separate control sphere might effectively require that the user can only access the private files, but not any other files on the system. If the program does not ensure that the user is only requesting private files, then the user might be able to access other files on the system.</html:p>
            <html:p>In either case, the end result is that a resource has been exposed to the wrong party.</html:p>
         </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: The product does not properly transfer a resource/behavior to another sphere, or improperly imports a resource/behavior from another sphere, in a manner that provides unintended control over that resource.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Unexpected State</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product does not properly transfer a resource/behavior to another sphere, or improperly imports a resource/behavior from another sphere, in a manner that provides unintended control over that resource.
cwe.name: Incorrect Resource Transfer Between Spheres

cwe.description: The product constructs pathnames from user input, but it does not handle or incorrectly handles a pathname containing a Windows device name such as AUX or CON. This typically leads to denial of service or an information exposure when the application attempts to process the pathname as a regular file.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>DoS: Crash, Exit, or Restart</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Other</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product constructs pathnames from user input, but it does not handle or incorrectly handles a pathname containing a Windows device name such as AUX or CON. This typically leads to denial of service or an information exposure when the application attempts to process the pathname as a regular file.
cwe.name: Improper Handling of Windows Device Names
cwe.extended_summary: Not properly handling virtual filenames (e.g. AUX, CON, PRN, COM1, LPT1) can result in different types of vulnerabilities. In some cases an attacker can request a device via injection of a virtual filename in a URL, which may cause an error that leads to a denial of service or an error page that reveals sensitive information. A product that allows device names to bypass filtering runs the risk of an attacker injecting malicious code in a file with the name of a device.

cwe.description: The code contains a control flow path that does not reflect the algorithm that the path is intended to implement, leading to incorrect behavior any time this path is navigated.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Other</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Alter Execution Logic</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The code contains a control flow path that does not reflect the algorithm that the path is intended to implement, leading to incorrect behavior any time this path is navigated.
cwe.name: Always-Incorrect Control Flow Implementation
cwe.extended_summary: This weakness captures cases in which a particular code segment is always incorrect with respect to the algorithm that it is implementing. For example, if a C programmer intends to include multiple statements in a single block but does not include the enclosing braces (CWE-483), then the logic is always incorrect. This issue is in contrast to most weaknesses in which the code usually behaves correctly, except when it is externally manipulated in malicious ways.

cwe.description: The product uses security features in a way that prevents the product's administrator from tailoring security settings to reflect the environment in which the product is being used. This introduces resultant weaknesses or prevents it from operating at a level of security that is desired by the administrator.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Varies by Context</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product uses security features in a way that prevents the product's administrator from tailoring security settings to reflect the environment in which the product is being used. This introduces resultant weaknesses or prevents it from operating at a level of security that is desired by the administrator.
cwe.name: Lack of Administrator Control over Security
cwe.extended_summary: If the product's administrator does not have the ability to manage security-related decisions at all times, then protecting the product from outside threats - including the product's developer - can become impossible. For example, a hard-coded account name and password cannot be changed by the administrator, thus exposing that product to attacks that the administrator can not prevent.

cwe.description: The product uses, accesses, or otherwise operates on a resource after that resource has been expired, released, or revoked.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>If a released resource is subsequently reused or reallocated, then an attempt to use the original resource might allow access to sensitive data that is associated with a different user or entity.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Other</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>DoS: Crash, Exit, or Restart</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>When a resource is released it might not be in an expected state, later attempts to access the resource may lead to resultant errors that may lead to a crash.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product uses, accesses, or otherwise operates on a resource after that resource has been expired, released, or revoked.
cwe.name: Operation on a Resource after Expiration or Release

cwe.description: The product does not prevent the definition of control spheres from external actors.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Other</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product does not prevent the definition of control spheres from external actors.
cwe.name: External Influence of Sphere Definition
cwe.extended_summary: Typically, a product defines its control sphere within the code itself, or through configuration by the product's administrator. In some cases, an external party can change the definition of the control sphere. This is typically a resultant weakness.

cwe.description: The product does not properly control the amount of recursion that takes place,  consuming excessive resources, such as allocated memory or the program stack.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
        <ns0:Consequence>
          <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
          <ns0:Impact>DoS: Resource Consumption (CPU)</ns0:Impact>
          <ns0:Impact>DoS: Resource Consumption (Memory)</ns0:Impact>
          <ns0:Note>Resources including CPU, memory, and stack memory could be rapidly consumed or exhausted, eventually leading to an exit or crash.</ns0:Note>
        </ns0:Consequence>
        <ns0:Consequence>
          <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
          <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
          <ns0:Note>In some cases, an application's interpreter might kill a process or thread that appears to be consuming too much resources, such as with PHP's memory_limit setting. When the interpreter kills the process/thread, it might report an error containing detailed information such as the application's installation path.</ns0:Note>
        </ns0:Consequence>
      </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product does not properly control the amount of recursion that takes place,  consuming excessive resources, such as allocated memory or the program stack.
cwe.name: Uncontrolled Recursion

cwe.description: The product performs the same operation on a resource two or more times, when the operation should only be applied once.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Other</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
		 '
cwe.summary: The product performs the same operation on a resource two or more times, when the operation should only be applied once.
cwe.name: Multiple Operations on Resource in Single-Operation Context

cwe.description: The product invokes a potentially dangerous function that could introduce a vulnerability if it is used incorrectly, but the function can also be used safely.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Varies by Context</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Quality Degradation</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Unexpected State</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>If the function is used incorrectly, then it could result in security problems.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product invokes a potentially dangerous function that could introduce a vulnerability if it is used incorrectly, but the function can also be used safely.
cwe.name: Use of Potentially Dangerous Function

cwe.description: The product performs a calculation to determine how much memory to allocate, but an integer overflow can occur that causes less memory to be allocated than expected, leading to a buffer overflow.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Memory</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>DoS: Crash, Exit, or Restart</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Execute Unauthorized Code or Commands</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product performs a calculation to determine how much memory to allocate, but an integer overflow can occur that causes less memory to be allocated than expected, leading to a buffer overflow.
cwe.name: Integer Overflow to Buffer Overflow

cwe.description: When converting from one data type to another, such as long to integer, data can be omitted or translated in a way that produces unexpected values. If the resulting values are used in a sensitive context, then dangerous behaviors may occur.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Unexpected State</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Quality Degradation</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>The program could wind up using the wrong number and generate incorrect results. If the number is used to allocate resources or make a security decision, then this could introduce a vulnerability.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: When converting from one data type to another, such as long to integer, data can be omitted or translated in a way that produces unexpected values. If the resulting values are used in a sensitive context, then dangerous behaviors may occur.
cwe.name: Incorrect Conversion between Numeric Types

cwe.description: The product performs a calculation that generates incorrect or unintended results that are later used in security-critical decisions or resource management.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>DoS: Crash, Exit, or Restart</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>If the incorrect calculation causes the program to move into an unexpected state, it may lead to a crash or impairment of service.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>DoS: Crash, Exit, or Restart</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>DoS: Resource Consumption (Other)</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Execute Unauthorized Code or Commands</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>If the incorrect calculation is used in the context of resource allocation, it could lead to an out-of-bounds operation (CWE-119) leading to a crash or even arbitrary code execution. Alternatively, it may result in an integer overflow (CWE-190) and / or a resource consumption problem (CWE-400).</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>In the context of privilege or permissions assignment, an incorrect calculation can provide an attacker with access to sensitive resources.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Bypass Protection Mechanism</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>If the incorrect calculation leads to an insufficient comparison (CWE-697), it may compromise a protection mechanism such as a validation routine and allow an attacker to bypass the security-critical code.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product performs a calculation that generates incorrect or unintended results that are later used in security-critical decisions or resource management.
cwe.name: Incorrect Calculation
cwe.extended_summary: When product performs a security-critical calculation incorrectly, it might lead to incorrect resource allocations, incorrect privilege assignments, or failed comparisons among other things. Many of the direct results of an incorrect calculation can lead to even larger problems such as failed protection mechanisms or even arbitrary code execution.

cwe.description: The product calls a function, procedure, or routine, but the caller specifies the arguments in an incorrect order, leading to resultant weaknesses.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Quality Degradation</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product calls a function, procedure, or routine, but the caller specifies the arguments in an incorrect order, leading to resultant weaknesses.
cwe.name: Function Call With Incorrect Order of Arguments
cwe.extended_summary: While this weakness might be caught by the compiler in some languages, it can occur more frequently in cases in which the called function accepts variable numbers or types of arguments, such as format strings in C. It also can occur in languages or environments that do not enforce strong typing.

cwe.description: The code does not function according to its published specifications, potentially leading to incorrect usage.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Quality Degradation</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The code does not function according to its published specifications, potentially leading to incorrect usage.
cwe.name: Incorrect Provision of Specified Functionality
cwe.extended_summary: When providing functionality to an external party, it is important that the product behaves in accordance with the details specified. When requirements of nuances are not documented, the functionality may produce unintended behaviors for the caller, possibly leading to an exploitable state.

cwe.description: The product calls a function, procedure, or routine, but the caller specifies too many arguments, or too few arguments, which may lead to undefined behavior and resultant weaknesses.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Quality Degradation</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product calls a function, procedure, or routine, but the caller specifies too many arguments, or too few arguments, which may lead to undefined behavior and resultant weaknesses.
cwe.name: Function Call With Incorrect Number of Arguments

cwe.description: The product calls a function, procedure, or routine, but the caller specifies an argument that is the wrong data type, which may lead to resultant weaknesses.

cwe.summary: The product calls a function, procedure, or routine, but the caller specifies an argument that is the wrong data type, which may lead to resultant weaknesses.
cwe.name: Function Call With Incorrect Argument Type
cwe.extended_summary: This weakness is most likely to occur in loosely typed languages, or in strongly typed languages in which the types of variable arguments cannot be enforced at compilation time, or where there is implicit casting.

         '

cwe.name: Function Call With Incorrectly Specified Argument Value

cwe.description: The product calls a function, procedure, or routine, but the caller specifies the wrong variable or reference as one of the arguments, which may lead to undefined behavior and resultant weaknesses.

cwe.description: The product, while copying or cloning a resource, does not set the resource's permissions or access control until the copy is complete, leaving the resource exposed to other spheres while the copy is taking place.

            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Application Data</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product, while copying or cloning a resource, does not set the resource's permissions or access control until the copy is complete, leaving the resource exposed to other spheres while the copy is taking place.
cwe.name: Permission Race Condition During Resource Copy

cwe.description: The product does not properly prevent access to, or detect usage of, alternate data streams (ADS).
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Non-Repudiation</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Bypass Protection Mechanism</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Hide Activities</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Other</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product does not properly prevent access to, or detect usage of, alternate data streams (ADS).
cwe.name: Improper Handling of Windows ::DATA Alternate Data Stream
cwe.extended_summary: An attacker can use an ADS to hide information about a file (e.g. size, the name of the process) from a system or file browser tools such as Windows Explorer and 'dir' at the command line utility. Alternately, the attacker might be able to bypass intended access restrictions for the associated data fork.

cwe.description: The product does not check for an error after calling a function that can return with a NULL pointer if the function fails, which leads to a resultant NULL pointer dereference.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>DoS: Crash, Exit, or Restart</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Execute Unauthorized Code or Commands</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Memory</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Memory</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>In rare circumstances, when NULL is equivalent to the 0x0 memory address and privileged code can access it, then writing or reading memory is possible, which may lead to code execution.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product does not check for an error after calling a function that can return with a NULL pointer if the function fails, which leads to a resultant NULL pointer dereference.
cwe.name: Unchecked Return Value to NULL Pointer Dereference
cwe.extended_summary: While unchecked return value weaknesses are not limited to returns of NULL pointers (see the examples in CWE-252), functions often return NULL to indicate an error status. When this error condition is not checked, a NULL pointer dereference can occur.

cwe.description: The code does not sufficiently manage its control flow during execution, creating conditions in which the control flow can be modified in unexpected ways.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Alter Execution Logic</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The code does not sufficiently manage its control flow during execution, creating conditions in which the control flow can be modified in unexpected ways.
cwe.name: Insufficient Control Flow Management

cwe.description: The product uses a denylist-based protection mechanism to defend against XSS attacks, but the denylist is incomplete, allowing XSS variants to succeed.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Execute Unauthorized Code or Commands</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product uses a denylist-based protection mechanism to defend against XSS attacks, but the denylist is incomplete, allowing XSS variants to succeed.
cwe.name: Incomplete Denylist to Cross-Site Scripting
cwe.extended_summary: While XSS might seem simple to prevent, web browsers vary so widely in how they parse web pages, that a denylist cannot keep track of all the variations. The "XSS Cheat Sheet" [REF-714] contains a large number of attacks that are intended to bypass incomplete denylists.

cwe.description: The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Bypass Protection Mechanism</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product.
cwe.name: Protection Mechanism Failure
cwe.extended_summary: This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

cwe.description: The product uses multiple resources that can have the same identifier, in a context in which unique identifiers are required.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Bypass Protection Mechanism</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>If unique identifiers are assumed when protecting sensitive resources, then duplicate identifiers might allow attackers to bypass the protection.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Quality Degradation</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product uses multiple resources that can have the same identifier, in a context in which unique identifiers are required.
cwe.name: Use of Multiple Resources with Duplicate Identifier
cwe.extended_summary: If the product assumes that each resource has a unique identifier, the product could operate on the wrong resource if attackers can cause multiple resources to be associated with the same identifier.

cwe.description: The product uses low-level functionality that is explicitly prohibited by the framework or specification under which the product is supposed to operate.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Other</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product uses low-level functionality that is explicitly prohibited by the framework or specification under which the product is supposed to operate.
cwe.name: Use of Low-Level Functionality
cwe.extended_summary: The use of low-level functionality can violate the specification in unexpected ways that effectively disable built-in protection mechanisms, introduce exploitable inconsistencies, or otherwise expose the functionality to attack.

cwe.description: The product performs multiple related behaviors, but the behaviors are performed in the wrong order in ways which may produce resultant weaknesses.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Alter Execution Logic</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
		 '
cwe.summary: The product performs multiple related behaviors, but the behaviors are performed in the wrong order in ways which may produce resultant weaknesses.
cwe.name: Incorrect Behavior Order

cwe.description: The product compares two entities in a security-relevant context, but the comparison is incorrect, which may lead to resultant weaknesses.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Varies by Context</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product compares two entities in a security-relevant context, but the comparison is incorrect, which may lead to resultant weaknesses.
cwe.name: Incorrect Comparison
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <html:p>This Pillar covers several possibilities:</html:p>
               <html:ul>
                  <html:li>the comparison checks one factor incorrectly;</html:li>
                  <html:li>the comparison should consider multiple factors, but it does not check at least one of those factors at all;</html:li>
                  <html:li>the comparison checks the wrong factor.</html:li>
               </html:ul>
         </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: The web application sends a redirect to another location, but instead of exiting, it executes additional code.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Alter Execution Logic</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Execute Unauthorized Code or Commands</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>This weakness could affect the control flow of the application and allow execution of untrusted code.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The web application sends a redirect to another location, but instead of exiting, it executes additional code.
cwe.name: Execution After Redirect (EAR)

cwe.description: The default error page of a web application should not display sensitive information about the product.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>A stack trace might show the attacker a malformed SQL query string, the type of database being used, and the version of the application container. This information enables the attacker to target known vulnerabilities in these components.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The default error page of a web application should not display sensitive information about the product.
cwe.name: J2EE Misconfiguration: Missing Custom Error Page
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <html:p>A Web application must define a default error page for 4xx errors (e.g. 404), 5xx (e.g. 500) errors and catch java.lang.Throwable exceptions to prevent attackers from mining information from the application container's built-in error response.</html:p>
            <html:p>When an attacker explores a web site looking for vulnerabilities, the amount of information that the site provides is crucial to the eventual success or failure of any attempted attacks.</html:p>
         </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: The product does not properly anticipate or handle exceptional conditions that rarely occur during normal operation of the product.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>DoS: Crash, Exit, or Restart</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Unexpected State</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product does not properly anticipate or handle exceptional conditions that rarely occur during normal operation of the product.
cwe.name: Improper Check or Handling of Exceptional Conditions

cwe.description: The product does not correctly convert an object, resource, or structure from one type to a different type.

b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">

         '
cwe.summary: The product does not correctly convert an object, resource, or structure from one type to a different type.
cwe.name: Incorrect Type Conversion or Cast

cwe.description: The product does not properly return control flow to the proper location after it has completed a task or detected an unusual condition.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>

               <ns0:Impact>Other</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product does not properly return control flow to the proper location after it has completed a task or detected an unusual condition.
cwe.name: Incorrect Control Flow Scoping

cwe.description: The product uses a name or reference to access a resource, but the name/reference resolves to a resource that is outside of the intended control sphere.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Application Data</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product uses a name or reference to access a resource, but the name/reference resolves to a resource that is outside of the intended control sphere.
cwe.name: Use of Incorrectly-Resolved Name or Reference

cwe.description: The product does not ensure or incorrectly ensures that structured messages or data are well-formed and that certain security properties are met before being read from an upstream component or sent to a downstream component.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Other</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product does not ensure or incorrectly ensures that structured messages or data are well-formed and that certain security properties are met before being read from an upstream component or sent to a downstream component.
cwe.name: Improper Neutralization
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <html:p>If a message is malformed, it may cause the message to be incorrectly interpreted.</html:p>
            <html:p>Neutralization is an abstract term for any technique that ensures that input (and output) conforms with expectations and is "safe."  This can be done by:</html:p>
	    <html:ul>
	      <html:li>checking that the input/output is already "safe" (e.g. validation)</html:li>
	      <html:li>transformation of the input/output to be "safe" using techniques such as filtering, encoding/decoding, escaping/unescaping, quoting/unquoting, or canonicalization</html:li>
	      <html:li>preventing the input/output from being directly provided by an attacker (e.g. "indirect selection" that maps externally-provided values to internally-controlled values)</html:li>
	      <html:li>preventing the input/output from being processed at all</html:li>
	    </html:ul>
            <html:p>This weakness typically applies in cases where the product prepares a control message that another process must act on, such as a command or query, and malicious input that was intended as data, can enter the control plane instead. However, this weakness also applies to more general cases where there are not always control implications.</html:p>
         </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: The product assigns an owner to a resource, but the owner is outside of the intended control sphere.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>An attacker could read and modify data for which they do not have permissions to access directly.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product assigns an owner to a resource, but the owner is outside of the intended control sphere.
cwe.name: Incorrect Ownership Assignment
cwe.extended_summary: This may allow the resource to be manipulated by actors outside of the intended control sphere.

cwe.name: Improper Adherence to Coding Standards

cwe.description: The product does not properly handle special paths that may identify the data or resource fork of a file on the HFS+ file system.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product does not properly handle special paths that may identify the data or resource fork of a file on the HFS+ file system.
cwe.name: Improper Handling of Apple HFS+ Alternate Data Stream Path
cwe.extended_summary: If the product chooses actions to take based on the file name, then if an attacker provides the data or resource fork, the product may take unexpected actions. Further, if the product intends to restrict access to a file, then an attacker might still be able to bypass intended access restrictions by requesting the data or resource fork for that file.

cwe.description: The product allows user input to control or influence paths or file names that are used in filesystem operations.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>The application can operate on unexpected files. Confidentiality is violated when the targeted filename is not directly readable by the attacker.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Execute Unauthorized Code or Commands</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>The application can operate on unexpected files. This may violate integrity if the filename is written to, or if the filename is for a program or other form of executable code.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>DoS: Crash, Exit, or Restart</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>DoS: Resource Consumption (Other)</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>The application can operate on unexpected files. Availability can be violated if the attacker specifies an unexpected file that the application modifies. Availability can also be affected if the attacker specifies a filename for a large file, or points to a special device or a file that does not have the format that the application expects.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product allows user input to control or influence paths or file names that are used in filesystem operations.
cwe.name: External Control of File Name or Path
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <html:p>This could allow an attacker to access or modify system files or other files that are critical to the application.</html:p>
            <html:p>Path manipulation errors occur when the following two conditions are met:</html:p>
            <html:div style="margin-left:1em;">
               <html:div>1. An attacker can specify a path used in an operation on the filesystem.</html:div>
               <html:div>2. By specifying the resource, the attacker gains a capability that would not otherwise be permitted.</html:div>
            </html:div>
            <html:p>For example, the program may give the attacker the ability to overwrite the specified file or run with a configuration controlled by the attacker.</html:p>
         </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: The product specifies permissions for a security-critical resource in a way that allows that resource to be read or modified by unintended actors.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Files or Directories</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>An attacker may be able to read sensitive information from the associated resource, such as credentials or configuration information stored in a file.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>An attacker may be able to modify critical properties of the associated resource to gain privileges, such as replacing a world-writable executable with a Trojan horse.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Other</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>An attacker may be able to destroy or corrupt critical data in the associated resource, such as deletion of records from a database.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product specifies permissions for a security-critical resource in a way that allows that resource to be read or modified by unintended actors.
cwe.name: Incorrect Permission Assignment for Critical Resource
cwe.extended_summary: When a resource is given a permission setting that provides access to a wider range of actors than required, it could lead to the exposure of sensitive information, or the modification of that resource by unintended parties. This is especially dangerous when the resource is related to program configuration, execution, or sensitive user data. For example, consider a misconfigured storage account for the cloud that can be read or written by a public or anonymous user.

cwe.description: The developer builds a security-critical protection mechanism into the software, but the compiler optimizes the program such that the mechanism is removed or modified.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Bypass Protection Mechanism</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Other</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The developer builds a security-critical protection mechanism into the software, but the compiler optimizes the program such that the mechanism is removed or modified.
cwe.name: Compiler Optimization Removal or Modification of Security-critical Code

cwe.description: The product constructs all or part of a command, data structure, or record using externally-influenced input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could modify how it is parsed or interpreted when it is sent to a downstream component.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>Many injection attacks involve the disclosure of important information -- in terms of both data sensitivity and usefulness in further exploitation.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Bypass Protection Mechanism</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>In some cases, injectable code controls authentication; this may lead to a remote vulnerability.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Alter Execution Logic</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>Injection attacks are characterized by the ability to significantly change the flow of a given process, and in some cases, to the execution of arbitrary code.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Other</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>Data injection attacks lead to loss of data integrity in nearly all cases as the control-plane data injected is always incidental to data recall or writing.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Non-Repudiation</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Hide Activities</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>Often the actions performed by injected control code are unlogged.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product constructs all or part of a command, data structure, or record using externally-influenced input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could modify how it is parsed or interpreted when it is sent to a downstream component.
cwe.name: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements in Output Used by a Downstream Component ('Injection')
cwe.extended_summary: Software or other automated logic has certain assumptions about what constitutes data and control respectively. It is the lack of verification of these assumptions for user-controlled input that leads to injection problems. Injection problems encompass a wide variety of issues -- all mitigated in very different ways and usually attempted in order to alter the control flow of the process. For this reason, the most effective way to discuss these weaknesses is to note the distinct features that classify them as injection weaknesses. The most important issue to note is that all injection problems share one thing in common -- i.e., they allow for the injection of control plane data into the user-controlled data plane. This means that the execution of the process may be altered by sending code in through legitimate data channels, using no other mechanism. While buffer overflows, and many other flaws, involve the use of some further issue to gain execution, injection problems need only for the data to be parsed.

cwe.description: The product provides an Applications Programming Interface (API) or similar interface for interaction with external actors, but the interface includes a dangerous method or function that is not properly restricted.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Execute Unauthorized Code or Commands</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Other</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>Exposing critical functionality essentially provides an attacker with the privilege level of the exposed functionality. This could result in the modification or exposure of sensitive data or possibly even execution of arbitrary code.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product provides an Applications Programming Interface (API) or similar interface for interaction with external actors, but the interface includes a dangerous method or function that is not properly restricted.
cwe.name: Exposed Dangerous Method or Function
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <html:p>This weakness can lead to a wide variety of resultant weaknesses, depending on the behavior of the exposed method. It can apply to any number of technologies and approaches, such as ActiveX controls, Java functions, IOCTLs, and so on.</html:p>
            <html:p>The exposure can occur in a few different ways:</html:p>
            <html:ul>
               <html:li>The function/method was never intended to be exposed to outside actors.</html:li>
               <html:li>The function/method was only intended to be accessible to a limited set of actors, such as Internet-based access from a single web site.</html:li>
            </html:ul>
         </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: The product does not adequately filter user-controlled input for special elements with control implications.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Execute Unauthorized Code or Commands</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product does not adequately filter user-controlled input for special elements with control implications.
cwe.name: Failure to Sanitize Special Elements into a Different Plane (Special Element Injection)

cwe.description: The product does not check or incorrectly checks for unusual or exceptional conditions that are not expected to occur frequently during day to day operation of the product.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>DoS: Crash, Exit, or Restart</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Unexpected State</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>The data which were produced as a result of a function call could be in a bad state upon return. If the return value is not checked, then this bad data may be used in operations, possibly leading to a crash or other unintended behaviors.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product does not check or incorrectly checks for unusual or exceptional conditions that are not expected to occur frequently during day to day operation of the product.
cwe.name: Improper Check for Unusual or Exceptional Conditions
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <html:p>The programmer may assume that certain events or conditions will never occur or do not need to be worried about, such as low memory conditions, lack of access to resources due to restrictive permissions, or misbehaving clients or components. However, attackers may intentionally trigger these unusual conditions, thus violating the programmer's assumptions, possibly introducing instability, incorrect behavior, or a vulnerability.</html:p>
            <html:p>Note that this entry is not exclusively about the use of exceptions and exception handling, which are mechanisms for both checking and handling unusual or unexpected conditions.</html:p>
         </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: The product does not handle or incorrectly handles an exceptional condition.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Other</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product does not handle or incorrectly handles an exceptional condition.
cwe.name: Improper Handling of Exceptional Conditions

cwe.description: The product does not return custom error pages to the user, possibly exposing sensitive information.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Read Application Data</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>Attackers can leverage the additional information provided by a default error page to mount attacks targeted on the framework, database, or other resources used by the application.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product does not return custom error pages to the user, possibly exposing sensitive information.
cwe.name: Missing Custom Error Page

cwe.description: A protocol or its implementation supports interaction between multiple actors and allows those actors to negotiate which algorithm should be used as a protection mechanism such as encryption or authentication, but it does not select the strongest algorithm that is available to both parties.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Bypass Protection Mechanism</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: A protocol or its implementation supports interaction between multiple actors and allows those actors to negotiate which algorithm should be used as a protection mechanism such as encryption or authentication, but it does not select the strongest algorithm that is available to both parties.
cwe.name: Selection of Less-Secure Algorithm During Negotiation ('Algorithm Downgrade')
cwe.extended_summary: When a security mechanism can be forced to downgrade to use a less secure algorithm, this can make it easier for attackers to compromise the product by exploiting weaker algorithm. The victim might not be aware that the less secure algorithm is being used. For example, if an attacker can force a communications channel to use cleartext instead of strongly-encrypted data, then the attacker could read the channel by sniffing, instead of going through extra effort of trying to decrypt the data using brute force techniques.

cwe.description: The product uses an API function, data structure, or other entity in a way that relies on properties that are not always guaranteed to hold for that entity.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Other</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product uses an API function, data structure, or other entity in a way that relies on properties that are not always guaranteed to hold for that entity.
cwe.name: Reliance on Undefined, Unspecified, or Implementation-Defined Behavior
cwe.extended_summary: This can lead to resultant weaknesses when the required properties change, such as when the product is ported to a different platform or if an interaction error (CWE-435) occurs.

cwe.description: The product uses a one-way cryptographic hash against an input that should not be reversible, such as a password, but the product does not also use a salt as part of the input.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Bypass Protection Mechanism</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Gain Privileges or Assume Identity</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Note>If an attacker can gain access to the hashes, then the lack of a salt makes it easier to conduct brute force attacks using techniques such as rainbow tables.</ns0:Note>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product uses a one-way cryptographic hash against an input that should not be reversible, such as a password, but the product does not also use a salt as part of the input.
cwe.name: Use of a One-Way Hash without a Salt
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <html:p>This makes it easier for attackers to pre-compute the hash value using dictionary attack techniques such as rainbow tables.</html:p>
            <html:p>It should be noted that, despite common perceptions, the use of a good salt with a hash does not sufficiently increase the effort for an attacker who is targeting an individual password, or who has a large amount of computing resources available, such as with cloud-based services or specialized, inexpensive hardware. Offline password cracking can still be effective if the hash function is not expensive to compute; many cryptographic functions are designed to be efficient and can be vulnerable to attacks using massive computing resources, even if the hash is cryptographically strong. The use of a salt only slightly increases the computing requirements for an attacker compared to other strategies such as adaptive hash functions. See CWE-916 for more details.</html:p>
         </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: The product correctly neutralizes certain special elements, but it improperly neutralizes equivalent special elements.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Other</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Other</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product correctly neutralizes certain special elements, but it improperly neutralizes equivalent special elements.
cwe.name: Improper Neutralization of Equivalent Special Elements
cwe.extended_summary: The product may have a fixed list of special characters it believes is complete. However, there may be alternate encodings, or representations that also have the same meaning. For example, the product may filter out a leading slash (/) to prevent absolute path names, but does not account for a tilde (~) followed by a user name, which on some *nix systems could be expanded to an absolute pathname. Alternately, the product might filter a dangerous "-e" command-line switch when calling an external program, but it might not account for "--exec" or other switches that have the same semantics.

cwe.description: The product uses a one-way cryptographic hash against an input that should not be reversible, such as a password, but the product uses a predictable salt as part of the input.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Access Control</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Bypass Protection Mechanism</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product uses a one-way cryptographic hash against an input that should not be reversible, such as a password, but the product uses a predictable salt as part of the input.
cwe.name: Use of a One-Way Hash with a Predictable Salt
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <html:p>This makes it easier for attackers to pre-compute the hash value using dictionary attack techniques such as rainbow tables, effectively disabling the protection that an unpredictable salt would provide.</html:p>
            <html:p>It should be noted that, despite common perceptions, the use of a good salt with a hash does not sufficiently increase the effort for an attacker who is targeting an individual password, or who has a large amount of computing resources available, such as with cloud-based services or specialized, inexpensive hardware. Offline password cracking can still be effective if the hash function is not expensive to compute; many cryptographic functions are designed to be efficient and can be vulnerable to attacks using massive computing resources, even if the hash is cryptographically strong. The use of a salt only slightly increases the computing requirements for an attacker compared to other strategies such as adaptive hash functions. See CWE-916 for more details.</html:p>
         </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: The product calls free() on a pointer to a memory resource that was allocated on the heap, but the pointer is not at the start of the buffer.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Memory</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>DoS: Crash, Exit, or Restart</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Execute Unauthorized Code or Commands</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product calls free() on a pointer to a memory resource that was allocated on the heap, but the pointer is not at the start of the buffer.
cwe.name: Free of Pointer not at Start of Buffer
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <html:p>This can cause the product to crash, or in some cases, modify critical program variables or execute code.</html:p>
            <html:p>This weakness often occurs when the memory is allocated explicitly on the heap with one of the malloc() family functions and free() is called, but pointer arithmetic has caused the pointer to be in the interior or end of the buffer.</html:p>
         </ns0:Extended_Description>
         '

cwe.description: The product attempts to return a memory resource to the system, but it calls a release function that is not compatible with the function that was originally used to allocate that resource.
cwe.common_consequences:
b'<ns0:Common_Consequences xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <ns0:Consequence>
               <ns0:Scope>Integrity</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Availability</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Scope>Confidentiality</ns0:Scope>
               <ns0:Impact>Modify Memory</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>DoS: Crash, Exit, or Restart</ns0:Impact>
               <ns0:Impact>Execute Unauthorized Code or Commands</ns0:Impact>
            </ns0:Consequence>
         </ns0:Common_Consequences>
         '
cwe.summary: The product attempts to return a memory resource to the system, but it calls a release function that is not compatible with the function that was originally used to allocate that resource.
cwe.name: Mismatched Memory Management Routines
cwe.extended_summary:
b'<ns0:Extended_Description xmlns:html="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:ns0="http://cwe.mitre.org/cwe-7">
            <html:p>This weakness can be generally described as mismatching memory management routines, such as:</html:p>
               <html:ul>
                  <html:li>The memory was allocated on the stack (automatically), but it was deallocated using the memory management routine free() (CWE-590), which is intended for explicitly allocated heap memory.</html:li>
